description:
Tonight I saw someone save the neighborhood from young loud obnoxious people. My friend and I were trying to have a nice night and a group of 6 in the corner were being incredibly loud. Someone stood  up and shushed them trying to maintain the atmosphere. It's Monday night and people just want to hang with their friends.

Why did the table have to yell "I pay your bills?"? And proceed to argue with the person. 

I'm sorry you feel entitled, but welcome to the city, don't ruin  a great bar young people.
author: Courtney F.

description:
I want to start by saying that this is one of favorite bars in the city. I was there on a date tonight when a group of people in the corner got a bit loud. Sure it may have been obnoxious but they just seemed to be having a good night.
Then a blonde woman in a tank top jumped up from her table and yelled "shut the f*** up" and began arguing with the group. She then stumbled over to the table and identified herself as the bar manager while telling the group to get the f$&@ out! How embarrassing and unprofessional for a manager who was clearly intoxicated to be addressing guests in this way. 
I had brought my date in to show them a great bar and was sadly disheartened by our experience. We left for another spot and honestly felt bad for the group that was singled out for enjoying themselves. I think a change in management might be needed, but for now I'll take my business elsewhere.
author: Paul C.

description:
I first visited this spot sometime in the mid-90s and I remember having a good time on those visits.

I recently started coming here again since I work somewhat close by.

On my recent visits it's been in the late afternoon and some good tunes were playing. The bartender has been friendly and I watched a cool old Hitchcock film playing silently in the background.

The white table cloths have always struck an incongruous note but overall it's a place worth returning to.
author: Art O.

description:
I had dinner with a friend next to this place and we decided to grab a drink afterwards at the lone palm. When we came in and sat down the bartender looked extremely unhappy to see us and when we asked if there were specials or a cocktail menu she smirked and said no. I'm not sure if it's because we were not locals because she seemed friendlier to other people sitting at the bar. 

I asked for a tanqueray Gin with Lime and she looked at me like I was asking for her to fly to the moon and bring me back a specimen.. so I said yes I like a lime with my Tanqueray please.. the bartenders head actually went back in astonishment and she widened her eyes as if to say what?! Are you crazy??   

If she wanted to double check if she had the right drink she could have asked but she said nothing the whole time.. just continued to make faces of confusion.
so she made me feel like an idiot and poured the drink...  it definitely wasn't in my head because the friend that I was with commented on the situation as well.. I felt so embarrassed and shamed for asking for a garnish? A Tanqueray Martini with a lime is not that uncommon! 

I have bartended for 6 years...and prefer the garnish of my choice minus the eye roll.

If you work in the service industry try to be friendly to your customers..it's called the service industry for a reason.. we moved because we did not feel too welcome at the bar and needless to say she did not get a tip.
author: Anya M.

description:
I love the Lone Palm. The bartenders are fantastic and on point! No nonsense drinks, a corner full of locals and the bar snacks are dangerously addictive. They're dog friendly, super accommodating and anyone who thinks otherwise, must be in the wrong place! 

I rarely review and have kept my review of Lone from posting, only because I want it to be my little secret place and not over run by non-locals ordering fancy-pants cocktails or turning it into a club/sports bar. Old classics are played here, and the vibe is chill.
author: Aoife G.

description:
I live down the block from this place and have always looked at it as my go-to-not-so-divey-dive-bar that feels like it should be on set in a weird 90's movie. I've always loved it, but stopping in this weekend was such a bummer. The dirty blonde bar tender (didn't catch her name) was so rude to me, and our visiting friends, that we ended up not even ordering drinks and heading down the street to the 500 club. 
Bummer town, population Lone Palm!
author: Shane W.

description:
The Lone Palm is kiiiind of like a dive bar, but with fancy shoes on. it takes all of the best elements of a classic dive (off the main drag, mostly uncrowded, very chill, no annoying hipsters or inflated prices) but manages to drop the less savoury elements (pretty clean, not too dark or dingy feeling, no vomit smell, no creepy local drunkards invading your space). i wouldn't have known about it at all though without a local taking me here, so it is something you have to seek out or be introduced to.

the whiskey sour i ordered was a little heavier on the sour/syrup than i would have liked, but was amenable overall. a cursory glance of their wall revealed a very respectable selection of booze, should you desire something more crafty (but not "craft" if you catch my drift). i thought the small dishes of freebie snacks were charming, although it should be noted that real food doesn't seem to be an option here--so just be prepared for that! 


overall a great spot to start the night!
author: Vicki L.

description: This is a dive bar with white tablecloths- the best kind of dive bar. A few times I've gone in there have been bowls of Goldfish on the bar- so great. Good date spot, friend hangout, whatever. I think they allow you to bring food in since they don't serve any but you should prob ask. Chill crowd, nice bartenders. Will be back at least twice a month.
author: Christine R.

description: I just got charged $17 for a Don Julio blanco and grapefruit--I've never paid that much for a cocktail in my whole entire life. This bar was amazing 10 years ago. I will never go here again.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Like a classy dive bar, if there is such a thing... it's a very casual ambiance yet the tables have tablecloths and they have dishes of snacks on each table like goldfish crackers, popcorn, etc.  Drinks are really well made but not overly expensive (by SF standards).  They have an excellent selection of vodkas, and there is even sparkling wine by the glass.

The ambiance is dark and cozy. Even when it's full, you can still have a conversation without yelling.

Staff are all super-nice.  Order at the bar - they do accept credit cards.
author: Rachel R.

description: This bar used to be great. Unfortunately they now charge $13 for well cocktails - that are not special or handmade. Sorry it's not right.
author: SF B.

description:
Love the Lone Palm! Unique cocktail bar. Full bar service. Plenty of tables. Variety of snacks are offered (complimentary) - nut mix, pub mix and goldfish. 

Good local beers on tap. Pretty good cocktails! 

As a preggo and then nursing mom who had a "drink" here, they don't charge for club soda. Sweet!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This is a true SF dive bar.

Great because my friend lives right across the street, so if we feel like going out but not going to far, this place is perfect. Cheap drinks, friendly bartender, and a good lineup on beer on tap. Bartender has a good knowledge of drinks, and will make the classics with no issues at all. Negroni and Old Fashioneds will not blow your pants off, but if you're just tryin' to hang wit da boyz this place is good enough. For those romantic dates, unless they're into that dive-y atmosphere, there are other more romantic places to impress the girl you brought (who's probably looking for some super sweet specialty cocktail anyways)

Dark, candlelit ambiance, and can get busy during weekends. The bar is pretty small, and can probably only fit about 40-50 people around small short tables. A good place to start off a crunk night, or chill for the entire night if you're looking to keep it more on the DL.
author: Albert C.

description: This bar feels like it's the nicest bar in a coal mining town, and for that, it'll always have a special place in my heart. Come in, stay a while.
author: Morgane M.

description:
This bar is one of my favorite places in all of SF. It has really great lighting, the bartenders are super accommodating, the drinks are great and they know what they are doing.
Know what you want- theres no drink menu here, so for all of you who can only order a drink that you read off a list, try another bar.
I'm blown away that they give out bar snacks for free during happy hour when their drinks are already discounted. You can't get anything for free anywhere! Plus that bar mix is SO good.
I had a well tequila cocktail during happy hour that was $8 and 100% agave, none of that weird grain alcohol stuff, it bumped to $10 after happy hour was over, but the drink was still just as delicious. For those of you with higher standards than well cocktails, I think for a dollar more I could have had Herradura, so I guess if you like that, it's worth the extra buck.
The music changes depending on who is working, I really like the variety.
It tends to be busy alot, so I think word has spread about this well established place. But you can still go in during the week days and have a nice quiet corner to yourself.
Weekends can be busy and sometimes there are customers who leave their half eaten food on the tables and all over those white tablecloths... GROSS! But the bartenders attitudes are great, we get served quickly and someone always comes by and cleans up the messes left behind. It's really impressive that such a small bar can pack such a big punch!
I've seen some bartenders handle obnoxious customers or underage folks trying to get served without id's and they are always really professional, even when those dopes argue with them! Like that will help your case? ha!
All in all if you're looking for good ambiance, great drinks, fun time and some people watching- this is the place for you. In a city that is constantly changing, its refreshing to come to a place that has stayed true since it opened.
author: Kerri D.

description: I came here to meet a few friends for drinks and didn't really love it. The mission is one of my favorite neighborhoods for food/drinks but for some reason this place just wasn't doing it for me. When I walked in, there were white tablecloths on all the tables which made it feel like a dive bar trying to make it a "fancy" restaurant. Confusing. There was also a man playing the accordion near our table then came around with a brown bag collecting tips. The drinks were fine, but I don't know if I would necessarily go out of my way to come back here.
author: Ilana B.

description:
This is my favorite bar in all of San Francisco. The drinks are well made, the beer cold, the bar staff friendly and interesting, and the location just off the beaten path enough to not be full of obnoious passers by. 

I'm comfortable when I'm here and I always feel like my money was well spent.
author: Trevor B.

description:
To date, this is definitely my favorite bar in San Francisco... because it reminds of the neighborhood bars back home in Chicago. 

It's chill, it's a little dingy but in the coolest way, It's really dark inside so you'll look great no matter how you actually look and they serve alcohol so you'll end up feeling great no matter how you actually feel. Oh, and I should mention they have a lava lamp and bar snacks if you get there early enough (helloooo complimentary shelled peanuts, pretzels, and goldfish crackers!).

The bartenders here a babes.
They don't have a drink menu and def don't ask about one. 
What you see is what you get and what you get are a handful of solid beers on tap, a few wine options, and oodles upon oodles of hard alcohol options... 
though I've always gotten the same thing: Moscow Mule. 

It's affordable and it's casual but you could also go for a sexy date and it would still work perfectly... plus, it's kitty corner from my favorite restaurant in San Francisco (Hoffmann's... def check it out) so you can really make a night out of it. One time I came with friends and we started the night at Lone Palm, left for dinner, and then came back to Lone Palm to close out the night because they do it right here.
author: Candice G.

description: I'm new to SF and so have been trying to find a spot where I can regularly grab a drink. I appreciate that Lone Palm is open late during the week, serves a decent drink, and has energy without being too loud to have a good conversation.
author: Jim S.

description:
Mellow crowd, sassy bartenders and a poor man's romantic decor. Don't ask for a cocktail menu because there isn't one. But don't be worried, the beverages are powerful. 

Good for dates, catch ups and family gatherings. This is not a place for bro-downs. Enjoy it while it lasts and see you soon.
author: Nick K.

description:
A "classic" San Francisco dive bar. 

I got my start in cocktails drinking Maker's Mark Manhattans at Lone Palm many, many moons ago. I was thrilled to see this Mission fixture still up and running after so many years. 

Lone Palm hasn't lost a step: the light is dim, old movies play on the tvs, and although the piano is missing the vibe is still very-much intact.  It's a great place to wind down after an evening or to start a night out. The exterior may seem uninviting but the interior has been luring people back for over a decade. 

You won't find crazy-fancy cocktails by snooty mixologists here, just solid drinks by down to earth people. When you're in the mood to get back to basics and want to get your dive bar on, this is the place to go.
author: Vlad L.

description:
This place is pure class, but you could probably tell from the font on the sign out front. Perfect for an intimate night with friends/great meet-up for people from Mission/Noe/Bernal. 

WHITE TABLE CLOTHES!!!
author: M G.

description: Classy bar, but classy in the old school sense of the word. Nice atmosphere, dark, good music, classic movies playing on the TV screen, decent drinks. This is how a bar is supposed to be.
author: Martino P.

description:
This place is SCREAMING 70's to me!!

70's vibes all the way. White tablecloths draped over every candlelit table. Black and white Charlie Chaplin playing on the TV. Curtains and velvety fabrics, and no table service. Yup, 70's anyone?

This place is great for dates or small tables--so it wasn't an ideal location for our party of 8, which eventually grew to more than 13. There's no waiter service or anything, and I only saw one barback darting around madly trying to grab glassware and clear tables. We didn't know what was protocol...were we allowed to move tables? 

Volume level is pretty ambient, but it eventually got louder to the point where I was comfortable with talking very loudly to be able to hear the people beside me. I had a lemon drop (more tart than sweet--YES!), and I liked their taste of moscow mules, and whiskey sours--although I'm not a whiskey girl myself. There's no menu, so this place is more of an old-fashioned/mature-vibes bar.

There's a restroom in the very back, but it's difficult to make your way through the crowd of low tablecloth bar tables and pool of bodies crowding the bar. I think this place would have been a better experience if our group was smaller and less confused. Still, if you're into that low-key and neon-lights ambiance, Lone Palm is for you!
author: Jodi H.

description:
Cool bar. Very Dashiell Hammett. Makes me want to call ladies "dames."

Decent drinks at decent prices. Dark setting, good place for a date or getting together with a small group of friends. Quality of drinks is a little hit or miss but this place remains an under-appreciated mission gem.
author: Baron C.

description:
Our friends had stopped here earlier, and liked it. so we decided we'd all come back after dinner.

It's a dive...but not exactly...White tablecloths? Not  the norm for a dive bar.
Definitely has the vibe of an old school loungey kind of place.

Seats were easy to find when we got there, and it was pretty chill. By the time we left it was packed, and LOUD.

Bartender was...eh, some drinks were better than others.

It's a pretty unique place, and I definitely return.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I love this place! It's great for a first date, because it's quiet enough to actually hear the person across the table. Sometimes it takes a while to get a drink, but the drinks are made well, and they are not too expensive. I like having table cloths and candles on the table. Can't call this place a dive, because it's chill and nice. But it's definitely a throw-back, if you like that sort of thing. (I do.)

I'm taking one star off, because the bathroom is clean but tiny. And I really do want my drinks made faster. 

There are so many places I won't go back to now that this place is on my list.
author: Jeremy T.

description: Cheap drinks, dim lights, germ infested snacks on the tables! This place is chill, low key and I'd say great for a tinder date you can't be bothered to spend money on. Well drinks around $4.50. Came on a Sunday night, place was full of tinder-dates. White table cloths and candles snazz it up just a bit. Bar is long with a lone palm on the end, just as name suggests. I'd come back or make this my local dive bar hang out.
author: Tallestbird R.

description:
My favorite bar in Noe Valley... Love the atmosphere and the staff is very kind.

Can be a good amount of tinder dates on certain nights. Weekdays are where this bar shines!
author: Rob H.

description:
I've always passed by this place, never really considered going there until a friend suggested that we meet there for cocktails.  It was a nice little spot, although not my typical Happy Hour fun spot to kick off the holiday weekend. It's always nice to find a new place to go to.

I arrived early and checked out the place a little. Plenty of seating, people meeting for cocktails, everything was nice without being fancy. They serve snacks on the tables, chips, crackers and such. I noticed that the place was quiet for a bar that wasn't empty, so it's a good place to meet someone to talk and have a pre-dinner cocktail. 

I ordered a Bullitt Manhattan up, it was perfectly done as any proper bar would do correctly. Whether it's a dive bar, a swanky lounge or anything in between - I would only expect the best from friends like mine.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
We had one of the worst experiences we've had in a long time, last night when we went to the Lone Palm. 

Yesterday evening at 7pm (11/6/2014) my fiance and I went to the Lone Palm to grab a cocktail before dinner. We'd been many times and have always been treated nicely. Last night changed our opinion of the place completely.

We walked in; no one was sitting at any of the tables and the actual bar was about 75% full. We sat at the end of the bar and waited patiently for the bartender to come over. After a few minutes, the only bartender ( a blonde girl ) came over and just looked at us. My girlfriend asked her "Do you do Mojitos". Bartender, "No". My GF "oh, what's your favorite cocktail to make?" Bartender, "Budweiser bottle". I then said, "Budweiser bottle is your favorite cocktail to make?", her response, "yep, I can just grab it and be done serving you". She then walked away from us as a rude smart ass would do. 

Here's the thing, I get it. I realize a bartender doesn't always have time to make a suggestion, but there are no cocktail menus on the counter and we just don't know what they could make. (obviously not mojitos). My GF was trying to be nice by saying she would try any easy cocktail that the bartender would make. Also, the bar was no where near full and she could have made a simple suggestion for a cocktail that is similar to a mojito. 

Now what she didn't know. We were out having a drink because we had just gotten some terrible news. We wanted to go out and just have a nice night out. This "little girl" with her bad attitude made an already sad day, that much worse. There is no room in the service industry (or in life, really) for people that spread their misery to others like that. We'll never be back and will be sharing this story with our other friends in the neighborhood that frequent the place. 

Owners need to fire this girl before she drives all of your patrons away.
author: Robert B.

description: Martini hits and misses. The more you drink the more you'll feel right at home at the Lone Palm.
author: Alexander T.

description:
3 C's peeps!!
Cute, Cozy and Cheap!!!!!
Perfect place for drinks after a lovely dinner date..
Love the music...
No cover charge.
Lovely decor everywhere.
Love the intimate tall tables against the wall.
Lots of seats and space to enjoy our drink.
Will definitely come back.
author: Claudine V.

description: Ordered a drink, gave a nice tip, asked for new pretzels since the bowl in front of me was pretty gross, and the bartender proceeded to insult me for my request with unjustified hostility.  One of those situations where you realize the other person must be going through some rough times in life, but since they let it affect their job and interaction with me, I have to rate this poorly and will never come back.
author: Scott P.

description:
My friends and I received terrible service from the girl bartending last night, Sunday the 10th. I spilled my ($5.50) vodka soda, and the bartender went out of her way to be rude while refusing to make me another one. 
The next round of drinks were made with no alcohol! All of them were just watered down soda water, after we had been consistently tipping for each drink. We left our drinks on the table and walked out.
author: Isabelle S.

description:
Very mellow bar out on Guerrero Street.  The atmosphere is super chill.  The tables all have small candles.  The bar is also dog friendly apparently because I saw two dogs running around when I was there.

This bar has hard cider (the brand was Fox Barrel) and it tasted like pear juice.  $4 for a bottle.

There are also separate men's and women's bathrooms and they were kept relatively clean (considering it is a bar).
author: Danielle C.

description: Love this place. It was great when I was in my early 20s, and still great now that I'm in my early 30s. Great bar for a date, a small group gathering, an intimate birthday celebration. Or mingling at the bar. The drinks are very reasonably priced, especially for SF. Get here early (before 9pm) if you want to snag a table on a Friday or a Saturday night.
author: Svetlana Z.

description:
BARTENDER SUCKS !!!!!  

My friend and I went to Lone Palm to meet up with our friends who had been served and were drinking their drinks.  To no avail, my friend and I waited patiently and attempted multiple times to get the bartender's attention.  At one point she said she would be with us shortly.  After this first and pathetic acknowledgment, she blatantly ignored us and then started to ignore our friends and reprimand them when they tried to get drinks.  FYI the bartender was a brunette female and was disgustingly cold and rude - I was actually in shock!! The bar was NOT crowded so aside from pure discrimination and caddy-ness there was no legitimate reason for her to so obviously ignore us and our polite attempts at getting her attention. This sort of "service" does not reflect the bar and it's hole-in-the- vibe but it definitely turned my friends and I away.
author: Katie L.

description:
This bar never disappoints (except when it does). Here's the key: go during the off hours. Those times when you need to go somewhere, but don't feel like committing to your bar-of-the-evening, start here. When you need a spot to take a break in, slake your thirst, and then move on - stop here. 

It looks like a leftover set from Miami Vice: neon signage, white tablecloths, mismatched furniture, and a dim ambiance. In 1980's Miami, this is the bar where you meet up with the stool pigeon who'll squawk for the right price. Here, it's a bar in the Mission. Adjust expectations accordingly. 

This is a good place to start a conversation, or end one. The 4 stars are really just for the ambiance and reasonable prices. (Some other posters have complained about the service - I've never had any problems).
author: Rob R.

description:
Sitting at the Lone Palm today, I decided I needed to come out of yelp hibernation for some of the places I just love. 

Here is a bar that has history. I remember when I moved here in '99, a friend brought me in saying it was his "best kept secret." He was dedicated to this place for it's Bombay martini (and the attentive lady bartenders, I'm sure). I was 21 then. After all these years it's still one of my favorite, remarkably unchanged, go-tos. The Lone Palm's authenticity is made evident by the clientele - its cool timeless quirk seems to filter out those in search of short-lived, mass appeal. The neighbors I meet here is what gives this place soul: a rare, genuine mix of young, old, blue collar, white collar, gay, straight, white, black. It's a tired discussion now, but in a city which is sometimes harder and harder to recognize, it's nice to know I can come here and feel like the city I love is close and familiar still.
author: Elle L.

description:
White table clothes, dingy lighting, and neon back lit bar, the Lone Palm makes you feel like you have taken a step back in time. Taking you back several decades, the Lone Palm has a lounge feel with an edge that cannot be replicated anywhere else in the city.

Easily one of my favorite bars to grab a drink with friends, the Lone Palm has music playing, but is not crazy loud so you can actually talk to your human friends... Novel Idea for a social establishment.

I encourage you to take a look at the Lone Palm and imbibe a delicious strong cocktail and sit back and enjoy the evening!
author: Justin O.

description: The service was good and bartender is friendly. The ambiance is chill and laid back with a dive bar feel and prices. Well drinks are only $4.50. I would recommend this place for a date night or out night out with friends.
author: Mary R.

description:
vibezzzz.

happy to have stumbled upon this spot. came here for a drink with a date - fun atmosphere for sure :)

feels like you're in Miami ( ok..I've never been but...one can IMAGINE ) hahah

will def come back when I'm in the area!!

** love the white tablecloths! c l a s s y
author: Selina W.

description: Stepping into Lone Palm is like stepping back into SF 1945.  White table cloths, tables nussled close together and black and a black and white movie playing next to soft neon lights.  I approve.  Cocktails are cheap around the $8 mark. defs worth the trip if your looking for a place in the Mission that isn't overwhelming.
author: Gabbi d.

description:
This is a friend's favorite bar so we wandered in late one Saturday afternoon. The atmosphere is a little off to me and I can't quite figure out why. Some combination of it being very dark, seemingly all the time, and the crowd. 

I will say the bartender we had was great. Attentive without being overwhelming and very helpful at helping a friend pick a drink when she wasn't sure what she wanted. Not every bartender handles that situation very well.
author: Harper Z.

description:
Lone Palm, so pleased to finally meet you. Neon sign and the lone palm tree outside - I immediately fell in love. (It's in the air, you know with that Vday approaching). 

Last eve, I hit up this Mission neighborHOod lounge/bar for a chill happy HOur.

LP has a cozy and intimate vibe, but at the same time feels spacious (when it's not uber crowded like how it was last night. I suspect it's like that during the week, but different on weekends).
AnywHO, I dig that the tables have white linens and candles, and agree with other Yelpies in that it's reminiscent of Miami (not that I've been) with the cool deco art-type vibe. 

i sat at the far end of the bar, and loved that we could hear each other and properly catch up. The digalicious chill tunes (from 80s to classic) were played at a tolerable volume.
Bartender was nice and attentive, and quick to refill our pretzels without having to ask.

OH or HOmylanta! Guess what yours truly was drinking? Gotta get dem HOegaardens on tap. Awwyah! Tasty belgian ale goodness! So happy to have the draft HOs two consecutive days in a row, and in different HOods. HOoray! So easy to please, right? :0

Wish LP was in my HOod, but you can't always get what you want. 
No worries tHOugh, as I shall definitely return to the LP.

Cheers my Yelp lovelies. Love, OX, XO, Ruv, and all that! Mmwah!
author: Gill C.

description:
I was a bit confused with this bar.

Something about the white table cloths made it seem like they are a bit more classy than it actually is. The drinks were good. Just get rid of those table cloths... Not good.
author: Berenice D.

description: I expected the bar to be a bit more lively.  My drink -- I ordered a  greyhound -- was alright. The bartender was really awesome and extremely friendly. The place was just a tad bit more lowkey than I had expected.
author: Israel R.

description: Love this place.  Super cool miami vice vibe.  Only thing is there is usually only 1 bartender so you have to wait.  Oh well!
author: Ashley F.

description: Never been more offended in my life.  Worst bar ever.  They harassed us to leave their bar so they can get drunk on the job after they rudely kicked everyone out.
author: Gilbert G.

description: Wow, this place is great! Can't believe I've never been in before. I was meeting with a friend. She doesn't even drink but she suggested this place just because she just likes the atmosphere.
author: Patrick S.

description: I can't add much that others have not. Candle lit tables in a bar. Music, well mixed drinks, good selection of liquor, cool vibe.
author: Will D.

description:
Time to play my favorite bar game at The Lone Palm, ask the bartender, what's the most offensively-named drink you know how to make?

Answer: The Last Word

OK, not the most vulgar thing I've ever heard of, but when I asked the bartender originally, she got embarrassed and ran off. I felt really awful at first, I spend my workday building people's self-esteem up so I feel like a jerk if I ever do the opposite, but then she came back and explained that a) she didn't want to say the names of the drinks, and b) they were all awful. So after we finished our drinks, she made us a pair of shots called The Last Word, which were gin, liqueur and lime juice. While it didn't qualify for the game, it was a classy move on the bartender's part, and thus, I thank her. She was great.

As for the bar itself, my friend wanted a divey place in the Mission. I didn't, but she had a rough day and wanted something low-key. There are plenty of dives in the Mission, but this one is less of a dive and more of a hideaway, and that's why I love it. Many reviewers have commented on the tablecloths, and yes, they have them and they are a nice touch. But the overall atmosphere of the Lone Palm is one of a found secret. If you're looking for a quiet place to have a drink that feels like nothing else in the Mission, come here. I'm glad that I did.
author: Kevin B.

description: Looks like on the weekends this turns into a crappy hipster bar but during the week it is a lovely watering hole.Old movies on the tv, strange decor, dim lighting. It is almost a wannabe dive without any of the nastiness that makes a dive what it is. It works though.
author: Disco B.

description: I adore this place! Dive bar in disguise. Love the white table clothes and candles. Cheap drinks and lovely ambiance. Friendly bartenders. Can't go wrong!
author: Michelle K.

description: Close by, cheap but tasty drinks, intimate atmosphere = perfect low key Friday night meet up spot with friends.   Good neighborhood bar that seemed to have a lot of first-daters there (cue awwwwwws) and is the perfect venue for it.  Music was great (Mariachi band sometimes pops in) and it never gets overly packed.
author: Raina D.

description:
White tablecloths, great bar, lounge feel. People are usually a teensy-bit more dressed up than your typical mission neighborhood bar. 

Can be a bit loud and warm, but this is my go-to spot for a drink that doesn't feel grungy. Good cocktails, too.
author: Ben M.

description: Bar is super cozy and dive-y, but the bartenders are rude and clearly don't want to be working. We asked for some Goldfish crackers (we read that they served them) and the chick responded, "that's for happy hour. We can't serve them after that because everyone wants them and it's too difficult." I'm sorry, but how is serving Goldfish "too difficult"?! Grow an arm and pour that shit in a bowl! How am I gonna get my puddings if I can't have any Goldfish?!
author: Blakely T.

description:
Classy. Great drink selection. Beautifully decorated and candle lit.
And Brooke Piazzi (gorgeous whole package of a woman bartender) makes a mean manhattan. 
Thanks Brooke for keepin it classy!
author: Cub H.

description:
So, I went to a birthday event, and somehow ended up doing a mini-bar crawl and tacos run. Epic win FTW! Use this as a template. First stop was "Mission Bar". This was the second stop, third was "Doc's Clock" before ending at "Taqueira Cancun".

Snickers at the name aside, this bar doesn't feel as divy as the other bars. Not saying it's not divy, just not as much (it's a lounge?). Small and cramped feel to it, since there are booths and small tables and high-tables with stools taking up space. 

The bartenders were friendly enough and the crowd matched. I would return.
author: Peter L.

description: There are not to many places in this world where you can run into David Lynch & John Waters to the glow of neon lights except one place the lone palm. At one point the corner store up the street had the largest rubber and ball over ever seen that mysteriously ended up on third street. Ok that's off subject but this bar is straight out of twin peaks & there is a feel if they added a smoke machine & and some cars music you could squint and be back in the eighties in an mtv video.
author: Urs F.

description: Awesome bar. Calling this place a dive is an insult. It's a bar. No food. Mostly liquor with 5 or 6 beers on tap and a few snacks(goldfish, pretzels and such). Bartenders are super friendly and the place is quite clean for a bar.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I've always enjoyed the Lone Palm's drinks and environment, but felt compelled to post a review after my experience this week. On Tuesday I stopped by the Lone Palm with a friend for drinks, and had brought a few checks in my pocket because I was planning to stop by the bank to deposit them afterwards.  The drinks were strong, and delicious, which is possibly related to my forgetting to go to the bank. The next day I couldn't find the checks anywhere! I was starting to panic, and then around noon I received a call from Jane, the owner at the LP. She had found the checks (they had fallen out of my pocket in the bar somehow); Googled the business that had cut them to get their phone number; called it to get my phone number; and then told me that she had them in a secure place for me to pick up that afternoon. Thank you Jane, you are amazing!

Moral of the story: If you are ever going to lose something of value in a San Francisco bar, I recommend the Lone Palm!
author: David C.

description:
Do you get bored midweek? 

Tired of needing to find a good pub quiz or music venue just so you have great music and a variety of people on a Wednesday or Thursday? 

That's why we come to Lone Palm (on weekdays) 

1. full house 
2. great ratio 
3. great bartenders 
4. good music (alt and indie rock, upbeat tho, and loud enough that u won't want to leave, but not so loud...except on the far end of the bar...that you can't carry on an awesome conversation) 
5. they take AMEX (sorry, but with this economic downturn, different gas prices, and my unfailing ability to miss my pocket when trying to redeposit cash, i love that card. it truly saves me at least 10-20 dollars a night since that's what I usually end up inadvertently dropping on the floor) 
6. for some reason, my Jameson -Rocks is the cost of a pint. (maybe I'm getting some kind of 'volume' discount....probably not something to be proud of tho)
author: Mike V.

description:
A cozy, little dive bar. Looks a little sketch from the outside with its neon sign, but such a pleasant surprise on the inside! Dimly-lit. Comfy and relaxed. Retro vibes. Cool decor. Oh, and the bathroom was pretty quirky/neat.

When it gets crowded, it's hard to maneuver around the tables and chairs that seem to be scattered about...but it's not a big deal.
author: Joanna M.

description:
If would be super fly if management could sit their female bartenders down and have a chat here. They are so unfriendly to fellow chicks but light up like the tree at 30 Rock when a dude asks for a whiskey. Umm... honey, I'm not your step mother. And, I also wasn't the one who circled your fat during sorority rush at UC Santa Barbara. I'm actually a straight up broad who can drink and always tips 20%. I'm also respectful to bartenders and servers. So, smile a little when I politely request a Hoegaarden. Don't sneer at me like I've asked to sleep with your boyfriend. 

This is a cute little place with a down-to-earth crowd in my favorite SF nabe. I'd love to give them more stars, but the girls in there need to woman up.
author: Lianne S.

description: Fun dive with a 50s feel, had a great time here. Was pretty loud on a weeknight after midnight. Ample seating with candle-lit, tablecloth high bar tables.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Yeah, been here many times before, but tonight--not so much.

My friend ordered a top shelf martini and as I walked up, he said to the bartender *and whatever she's having* to add to the order.  The bartender promptly turns around, right in my face,  goes to the register, types something in and comes back with *$11*.  
I'm like *Uh, how can you know how much it is when I haven't even told you what I want yet?*.  
He looks confused and says *No, it's $11 for HIS drink.*.
I'm like *For a MARTINI???*
He says *Well, he asked for Hendricks, which is $9, and then because of the martini glass, it's an extra $2*.
Um WHAT??  Were you gonna serve it in his HAND for $9?  How else would you serve a martini but in a martini glass???

And on top of that, when he first went to order, he said the bartender asked him if he wanted an olive or an onion in his MARTINI.  I suggest going back to bartender school if you think a martini EVER has an onion in it, ESPECIALLY an $11 martini!!  
Can you say *Gibson?*  I thought not.

Fuck this place.
author: D C.

description:
Worst. Bar. EVER. If you enjoy being mistreated, this is your place to be. Masochists, this should be your new hangout.
I came here a month ago with my husband and a colleague from work. The bartender was rude to my husband. I left my nice French Connection sweater at the bar. A day later, I called and received confirmation that it was in the lost and found. I couldn't pick it up then (we all have lives, you know?). Two days later, I called and a nice woman who worked at the bar said it's no longer there but she'll text everyone who worked at the bar the day I left it. I appreciated her efforts and thanked her. It was to no avail and then I called again, left a message, and said it's got to be there because it was there before.
Then - get this!- I get a minute-and-a-half voicemail on my phone that started nicely and said they're sorry I lost the sweater but they don't have it. Fine. It should've stopped there. No. The woman who called proceeded to tell me a didactic story about how she left $200 sunglasses at a cafe but then - lo and behold!- she called the cafe and left her name and number - and got them back. WTF, lady? I don't need to hear about your douchey sunglasses and what I didn't do. And then she told me that everyone knows about my sweater and to not call the bar again!
A+ for customer service!
After I checked in the bar one last time by actually dropping in, the bartender pretended she didn't know my story, then dumped a whole bunch of sweaters on a neighboring table (this is how mine was stolen), and then told me that everyone already knows about my sweater and not to bother the bar!
On top of that, today, two weeks after this happened,  I get a 3-minute aggressive voicemail telling me to move on and blaming for being grumpy! How do you like that! I'm sorry, but if you call someone a month after the incident and leave a three-minute nasty message, that has only one name: harassment.
I will make it my personal mission to tell all my friends and yelpers to not set foot here again. Unless they're itching for their clothes to be stolen and dying for negative vibes and an agressive attitude.
There are much nicer and friendlier bars in the Mission, believe you me.
author: Lastochka S.

description: We tipped the broad at least $15. My friend spilled her drink and the bartender refused to make another cheap vodka soda.  We decided to leave when our next drinks were poured at $5.50 a piece and she decided to leave out the alcohol. We walked out after receiving nothing but dirty looks from the bartender, not to mention the non-alcoholic beverages we did NOT order. She ended up trying to charge my friend a tip on her credit card without asking. As if one drink deserved gratuity. My friend got the pre-charged money back and we went across the street. The Liberties is awesome.
author: Kaitlin T.

description: The name of this bar makes me think of masturbation. I like that I can nosh on pretzels and goldfish while I'm drinking. And the white tablecloths remind me of classier bars from classier times, like in that movie I've never seen, Casablanca. Or "Classyblanca," which is what they should call this place if they ever rename it, which I don't think they should.
author: Kent L.

description: Good dive bar low prices good service and no thrills. A great local joint with a good reputation.
author: Livia M.

description: I actually really love this place, its perfect for getting a drink, after your drink after work. I work close and can come here and hang out after work with friends and coworkers.  Bartenders are cool and friendly. They have fun snacks, like flavor blasted goldfish which I love, but they are basically like crack and very addicting. And you really don't wanna think about everyone who just digs their hands into those delicious snacks after the bathroom, but you don't think like that when you are a couple drinks deep. But anyways I have had everything here from gimlets to moscow mules, and the classic boiler makers.  I do think this place has a shit ton of mirrors almost too much, and they have all these different size tables so you feel like Alice and Wonderland after she takes those pills walking around that place.
author: Chrissy C.

description: Timeless, ageless, cool place, with a good, relevant name b/c of the lone palm that sits in front of it. Like the art deco vibe, and the relaxed atmosphere. Not too loud or raucous, but you still feel relevant. Good.
author: Andrew K.

description: It seems like a lot of people have had problems with the bartenders at Lone Palm, but I've never had any issues.  Some times it takes a bit of time to get a drink, but its always crowded when thats an issue.  They have Racer 5 on tap, which rapidly turns my brain to mush, so thats cool too.  Overall, 4 stars for you Lone Palm.  You should be proud of yourself...you earned it.
author: Kelvin B.

description:
I didn't even know this place existed until this weekend. We went there on Saturday night. The music was awesome, the bartenders were rad (they make a sick old fashioned here).

I'll definitely be back. It's a really chill spot. A dive with good drinks. Hell yeah.
author: josh m.

description:
Used to be one of my favorite places to have a drink on a weeknight (avoided it like the plague during the weekends, since it just turns into a yuppies-disguised-as-hipsters crowd). 
Last night, someone thought it was a brilliant idea to throw a party there and invite every friend they have. The bar is wayyy nicer when it's not crowded. I would never consider it a good place to throw a party. Go to Zeitgeist or El Rio if you're going to do that. It was awful. The bartender didn't handle it very well. She was slammed. I was beyond patient, given her situation. However, she was beyond rude to me when I asked for a couple cocktails for me and my friend at the table. I WAITED FOR 15 MINUTES ONLY FOR YOU TO ROLL YOUR EYES AND ME AND SAY NO?!? She then moved past me to the jerk in the popped collared shirt who waited for only 1 minute and helped him. 

I walked away, and took my money elsewhere.

Never going back there. Not until they get rid of the B that was working the bar that night.
author: Shawne B.

description: The Lone Palm is a simple, quiet and almost intimate neighborhood bar. Small and okay beer selection. Friendly bartenders, candlelit tables, and usually not too crowded.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Nice place to have Happy Hour with co-workers. Nothing posh or blingy, just a nice, inexpensive, cool and quiet spot to have drinks with pals.  ;)

But after we got in, of course...the crowd grew to a decent size for the bar.

I'd go back again.
author: Nan P.

description: You want to meet people by sparking up conversations about why the bartender is organizing napkins and working is if she is closing down the bar while not paying attention to everyone waiting for drinks, this place is great. Everyone comes up with a theory of what medication they are on....I met lots of confused people.
author: Jason H.

description:
Terrible service. Specifically from the young girl who bar tended on Sunday night the 10th. She was unfriendly from the start and overcharged my credit card. I don't know why the management would choose to let one rogue bartender ruin the experience of a seemingly classy bar. 

 If you're in the neighborhood, go across the street to The Liberties. They know what good service is.
author: Chris W.

description:
Cute little bar - looks dive-y from the outside, but inside it's clean and there are tables set up with pretty white cloths to add an air of class to the place. Pretty crowded, but it was a Saturday right after a Giants game. The bartenders were nice and got to everyone quickly.

Had a good selection of beer with some micros on tap - I really wanted to try the Hell or High Watermelon, but I was driving! Maybe next time =] Liquor selection looked pretty extensive as well. 

Clientele seemed pretty friendly, which is always a bonus - we had a group of six and could only find room to stand by the bathroom, and no one shoved their way through like you sometimes see in crowded bars.

It's also close to the Mission, which is always a bonus!
author: Dawn S.

description:
I had a very bad experience with the bar tender who worked at this bar. The customers there seemed very pleasant and the bar seemed to be a standard bar. However, this is my story and judge it as you may -

I have never been to the Lone Palm before but I was at a house party around the corner with ten other guys and girls and they invited me along around midnight to the Lone Palm. We walked the two blocks over there and entered the bar without being IDed or running into anyone at the door. We purchased an assortment of drinks at the bar, roughly one for each of us.

So we are standing there having our drinks and the bar tender came around from the bar and told one of the party that he had to leave now, and kicked him out. As it turned out he had carried a beer into the bar that he had been drinking at the party. He apologized, gave his beer to the bar tender and left without a scene.

I approached the bar tender and apologized for my friend bringing a beer and explained that it was an accident. She told me that we were not allowed to bring our own alcohol into the bar. I told her that we had just bought a round of drinks as a party and once again told her that it was an accident and that we did not mean to be rude or break any rules and asked if she would allow our friend back into the bar. She told me that if she "caught any of us trying to sneak liquor into the bar again" she'd kick the entire party out.

I promptly left. Again this is one experience that I had so it obviously may not be the norm at this bar but it was very insulting and pretty irrational.

We had just walked into the bar and bought well over $100 dollars in drinks, we were not belligerent or making a scene, one of us happened to still have the half-empty can of beer from the party in his hand. I understand the policy and why you can't allow people to bring outside alcohol into a bar. However, she easily could have taken the beer and said "sorry you can't bring alcohol in here." It would have been no problem whatsoever. Instead her reaction was rude, illogical and very frustrating. Furthermore, she was obnoxious and accusing us of "sneaking" alcohol into the bar was absurd.

I won't be going back there.
author: Nick T.

description:
Dimly lit and cozy, with white tablecloths, candles, soft neon, and a Miami circa 1953 feel. 

It's perfect for a first date- and actually, when I was last there, a fella asked me if I was Veronica. Ten minutes later another guy came up and asked me if I was Kelly. Proof that this is a real blind date spot.

They play good music (think Cat Power and Hank Sr), and it's calm enough that you can have a conversation without feeling like you need to yell.

Bonus points for the ladies room: Rosewater, hairspray, and other niceties.
author: Amanda R.

description:
In one corner, over typical over crowded mission bar. In the other, intimate conversations over candlelit white table cloths. Too much of a juxtaposition; just confused cluttered ambiance. The retro vibe they're going for is totally unauthentic. 

"Dive with class"? Dive, my ass!
author: Halley B.

description:
This could be my new favorite bars in the mission.  Love the white table cloths and the long bar.

This place looks like a total dive...maybe it sort of is, but it's oh soooo cool.
author: Josh D.

description: New favorite bar in the Mission...there are enough tasty snacks to make you good and thirsty for a tasty beverage at this art deco-ey dark bar!   The bartender was really warm....it was earlish on a Friday, not sure what the 'scene' is like later in the night, but highly recommend!
author: Brye L.

description: This bar is very close to where I live so whenever I find myself craving for a drink or two I come here.  Good ambience and music, the toilets are always clean and it never gets too crowded that it gets stifling.  The bar tenders know their cocktails but often hesitate when you ask them for suggestions.  Encountered a not so pleasant bar tender one Wednesday but oh well still a good place to hang out.  The people who go there are usually within the neighborhood so it's easy to start a conversation with someone when you go there alone.
author: Janis P.

description: Goldfish and table cloths are nice. Reminds me of cheesy-fun LA lounge bars. Very cool spot in that sense (asthetically, I mean.) still, the beers taste kinda weird, like stale? Maybe the faucets are old or something. And the 50 cent price hike is lame.
author: Clark L.

description: Walked into the bar thinking it looked like a cool place, but then had an awful experience with the bartender on my first time there.  She was immediately rude, made our second round of drinks WITHOUT alcohol, and then tried to give herself a tip on my tab as I was closing it out.  Terrible customer service!  There are tons of great bars in the mission but apparently the Lone Palm is not one of them.
author: Anna B.

description: It feels like a scene out of a David Lynch movie in all the right ways. Dog-friendly, human friendly.
author: Antonia T.

description:
W O W

Giving a dive bar the highly coveted 4 stars from me.

I came here on the advice of my date, since our long walk along Chrissy Field turned into dinner at Regent Thai, and inevitably ended up here because the date was going that well.  He knew of this place (I did not) so in I went, rather with trepidations.

What a riot.  After ducking underneath the death valley blanket of carcinogens guarding the entrance, I found a cute area set off by linens over small round tables.  Linens?  In a dive bar?  

I was feeling warm from the glass of white wine earlier, so the bartender told me right off that a nice cold Pear Cider would not affect the wine already coursing through my veins.

I sipped it and it was light, fruity, not overly sweet, and enjoyable.  My date and I hung out there for another two hours.  Wow, what a great event.  I'm marking this one on the calendar as a reminder of the good days when I'm 70.

The bathroom here was clean and swept clean, almost on the hour, since I found it immaculate for a dive bar.  The counters are easy to rest your elbows on and for the ladies, little hooks to hang your coats and other necessary items of adornment.  Amidst the very modern music, they had an old b&w movie playing.  Surreal, really.

My date ended approximately around 11-ish and we already set another one for this Thursday.  I've decided to not judge bars from their seedy outside until I've finally gone in.
author: Miika M.

description:
Always a great place for drink. Full bar, liquor + beer wine. And the tablecloths just make the place feel charming and classy. What more can you say about a bar other than that ?

Avoid big parties, there just isn't room to move in that place, more than 6 people and you're in for an adventure.
author: Geoff H.

description:
The single lone palm tree in front of the spot really sealed the deal for me. Not to mention, a nice and friendly bartender who even took the time to politely answer my drink questions didn't hurt my review of this place either. I'm partial to bourbon, so I ordered a Manhattan first and a Sazerac second. Both were made excellently and quickly, not to mention they were under 7 bucks a pop! 

The place isn't too hipstery, though I did notice a couple of dudes with ugly mustaches, and the overall ambience is rather chill and old school speakeasy-ish.  I'd definitely recommend this place for a group of friends or if you just feel like chilling at the bar and knocking a few down the hatch.
author: E-dough R.

description:
It's a nice, understated chill place.  Quiet enough to talk, not packed with sloppy drunks, just a good neighborhood bar a notch above a dive, almost a lounge without the pretension.

It's really nothing special, but cool energy hovers this little Mission waterhole.

Packed with locals and not packed with people overly excited about being in "The City."

Parking sucks, deal with it.

Have been here a small handful of times and figured I should probably announce I'm a fan. :)
author: Athena S.

description:
And so this is my arc.  The end of my arc, perhaps.  I sit at the bar.  Alone.  Two beers in.  Next beer will be a whiskey, and so will the one after that.  

The place is mostly empty.  Sunday night.  The drinks come quickly.  The bartender is pretty.  Dark hair.  Light eyes.  Tight purple shirt.  She glows under the blue and pink lights above us.  There are two men chatting with one another further down the bar.  There is a group of six or eight women in the corner, hipsters, with checkered dresses and thick-framed glasses, laughing and generally engaging in revelry.  The music that is playing is some old soul record I've never heard before.  Good jukebox, I think.  

All these people here.  I am alone.  She is all over my mind.   

I order another whiskey.
author: P. William G.

description:
Ah... Lone Palm, 45 steps from my apartment - yeah, I counted (note to weirdos:  you don't know in which direction, so don't even try to figure it out).

My local bar in Vermont had a constant rotation of Beck's "Odelay" (good album, but after the 500th time, you're ready to move on), Hootie and the Blowfish (no one's ever going to be drunk enough to enjoy that), and AC/DC (or was that the bar in Ohio)?  Well, having a neighborhood bar that plays Hot Chip, Fujiya & Miyagi, the Cure, Spoon, Okkervil River, etc, is quite fabulous.  

On the other hand, no one needs to hear Radiohead at a bar.  I'll give you "Talk Show Host" around 7pm, Lone Palm.  After that, you're just asking to find me sobbing in the corner of the tastefully decorated restroom.

Also, I can't keep talking behind your back anymore.  I just have to tell you, up front, what people have been saying.  Your drinks taste, well, soapy.  And, given your name...it was only a matter of time before someone thought of it:  "The Lone Palmolive."

Maybe you could hire me as a part-time bar back?  Those glasses REALLY need an extra rinse.
author: Alissa K.

description:
Judging by the outside that is mainly lit from an 80's looking neon sign, you would think this place is a total dive. However, once you walk inside you'll notice that the bar has some life to it and on occasion, there can be some decent eye candy. The only peeve that I had when I went was that the bartender was impatient and not the best greeter.

Overall, it's a fun place to head to with some friends, or if you're on a date.
author: Alfonzo J.

description: dive bar with great wine and white table cloths.
author: Tara G.

description: I love this place! It is a perfect combination of laid back and classy. Though it was opened in the 1980s, the atmosphere always has me half expecting to run into Rick and Ilsa. The bartenders are efficient and knowledgable- stirring up fine martinis and side-cars, and our dog, Lola, is welcome. It's also rather intimate and romantic before about 10pm, when it starts to fill up. Even then, it's a chill local crowd who mostly seem to have that most elusive of traits, as of late- good manners.
author: Mishka L.

description:
2 times bad service here.  Too bad, because the crowd is good.

First time the bartenders (who shall remain nameless/descriptionless) seemed to just be tired and not giving a flying donkey fuck about smiling or even saying hello.  Ok fine.  We don't all posses my magic bullshitting skills. I can deal. But a good bartender who isn't busy will shoot the shit for a couple of seconds and feign SOME enthusiasm.

A friend convinced me to give it another shot, so I did.

The second time was even worse.  I ordered a drink while we figured out shots.  No drink, let alone shots (which took us 10sec to decide).  The other bartender took 10-15min to approach us.  Simple mistakes?  Nah. Bartender #1 talked back my order and wasn't that busy. He/She wasn't high, so WTF am I supposed to think?  That they're incompetent? They seemed decently well-seasoned to me. Bartender #2 was cool, but slow to engage us.

I might as well have gone to http://www.yelp.com/biz/nicks-corner-store-san-francisco#hrid:gbMgTcLOLUd5p-XdMfUt7Q and purchased drinks for brown-bagged consumption on the streets.

I may come back cos my friends like the place, and to give these human beings another shot.  Maybe these were honest mistakes, and a chain of coincidences.  But I'm not impressed.
author: David D.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that you don't want to know me when I haven't eaten. My blood sugar drops and I very quickly get in foul mood (my BF will attest). Unfortunately this tends to happen a lot at the end of the day when it's time for happy hour. 

What a pleasant surprise to walk in to the Lone Palm and see bowls of different treats on every table: Goldfish crackers, nuts, BBQ Pop Chips, Chinese Crackers, etc. I was in snackers heaven (I may or may not have eaten two entire bowls to myself - just sayin'). 

I can't really base my review alone on the fact that they have good bar nibbles which is easy because the drinks are great here. I was a little surprised at the price, $10 for a martini, when it really is at the end of the day a dive bar. Nonetheless, I'm not holding it against them. 

Looking forward to coming back!
author: Julia N.

description:
Voted, by me, as the bar most likely to find someone outside smoking something funny. Maybe that's why there is usually such a mellow crowd inside. 

I really do love this place and wish I still lived across the street. Good beer selection, no food but awesome burritos (La Altena)  and ok pizza down the block. It does seem that every night I am here, whether it be before or after, I wind up totally hammered. Anyways, if your looking for a chill spot to have some good times with some good friends, this is the place.
author: Michael C.

description:
Came here with a friend and one of her friends after seeing a show at the GAMH. The night was going welland I was having pretty good converstation with my friend's friend. Then one of her male co-workers shows up. Talk about C-Block. Pretty soon after my friend gets kinda wasted and it all goes down hill from there. So we call it a night.

I'm not one to blame the venue for the situation however. The place was pretty cool. An off the beaten path neighborhood bar. From the grungy outside you'd think it would be a rough bar but it's quite nice and calm. Noise levels are acoustically perfect for a conversation. Not too loud where you have to yell, not too quiet where it would be akward to speak. They've got Guinness and the crowd is pretty laid back. If I lived nearby, it would probably be a local haunt  but alas I'm scarred now from my one visit. To quote Stellah D's review:

Lone Palm Indeed.
author: Kim N.

description:
The Lone Palm is an oasis of sorts.  The tablecloths are very Casablanca.  I like it because I'm usually not the oldest skirt here, it's not too loud and it's a bit removed from the usual Mission playpen.  It's very unlikely you'll get in a bar fight here.  

A long, long time ago, I learned that the owner of this bar's philosophy is that hiring good-looking staff will make your bar successful.  And this seems to have worked for him.  Sadly, it's a philosophy with a dark side, which I will generously describe as lackluster service.  "I'm too sexy to take your order, too sexy to make eye contact, so sexy it huuuuuurts..."

I saw Daniel Handler (or Lemony Snicket, if you prefer) in here once and accosted his table -- much to his discomfort and dismay.  Goes to show, in this urbane environment of soft candlelight and white tablecloths, you may not notice that you are, in fact, in the pisser.
author: Rosie W.

description: Nice bartenders, good drinks (I love being served a moscow mule in a silver cup), chill vibe on the weeknights/bustling on the weekends. A little oasis that can be both chill and nice but also have a little bit of a dive bar edge. Solid neighborhood bar.
author: Erin H.

description:
This place is walking distance from my new digs. This makes me happy!  Lone Palm has a cool, deco-type vibe which is as close to Miami as I care to ever be, so it is perfect. 
Weekends are really crowded, so get there early or don't expect to find a place to sit. If you do get one of the white tablecloth covered tables, it's a great way to people watch, and it isn't too, too loud, so you can still have a conversation with your friends. 
The music is schitzo. Some nights it is great, others it is terrible. I'm guessing it's the bartender's choice? The bartenders are the typical standoff-ish type that you normally find in the Mission, but they get your drinks in reasonable amount of time, so that's cool with me. 
All in all, I'm very pleased to have this place as one of my locals, and that I only have to walk a block to get home. Works for me!
author: Susie D.

description: Great local bar.  Nothing fancy, but it's going to be the place you end up with all your friends for a pre- or post-dinner drink and merriment.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I really really really want to love this place as its got just the right amount of funky to it.  An ex of mine worked there years and years ago and I remember going to meet her, or even pick her up, and having to deal with a tidal wave of smoke (mind you this IS after the smoking ban in CA). So I avoided it like the plague.

So now there is no smoking so I figure its safe for a trial run on a Friday night. In the spirit of full disclosure; I worked a gig that night and lugged a ton of gear in and out of my truck and the venue, so I was tired. I also hadn't really eaten anything remotely of substance that day and had 2 beers. So I was on the fast track to nap-ville on my couch when I ventured out.

I have to say that the crowd was actually pretty cool. Granted 1/3 of the place was my friends, but still, everyone seemed interesting and varied. There was one horrible idiot yelling and speaking as loudly as humanly possible, but that happens everywhere...So far so good.

Perhaps the above info contributed, but all I wanted to do was have a few drinks, loosen up, and hang with the crew. The problem with rating a bar, specifically a dive-bar, is that its mostly based on the patrons, the price, and the service. I'm a DJ and complete music snob but I could care less about what's playing in a dive-bar so long as its not ridiculous. (and by care less, i mean, ALMOST ANYTHING is acceptable and gives the bar its "divey character") I also don't really deduct any points for decor unless its smells like urine (think: carpet at storyville), or is a little too chichi for what it really is. It should be dark, weird, and even confusing; check.

So we have people: good; prices: not bad; service: a roll of the dice. After waiting 10 minutes for one bartender to finish chatting with friends (mind you I was standing right next to one of said friends), I finally got some service. Ten minutes in a small bar way under capacity, while tired and almost hung over from 2pm drinking, is an eternity!!! Honestly if she had said, "hold on a sec", I'd have been fine. 

The funny thing was the other bartender was busting ass to cover the rest of the bar, get ice, restock, etc. Anyway, I get this ditzy, "hi" like she's surprised I wanted something. I order, and get a very weak drink. I kinda figured it might just be that type of place, but upon getting a good pour, smile, and proper acknowledgement from the other taller bartender, I realize some people are just not made for the service industry.

Am I being picky? Yeah a little. But first impressions mean a lot, and it wasn't that busy. So perhaps I'll go again and even give her one more try, but until then, 3 stars is what we have.
author: Morgan A.

description:
I wanted to write this a while back...

This place is great. Comfortable, great ambiance and the white table clothes keeps it classy. I also noticed that the crowd was mellow, just groups of people hanging out (instead of a rancid meat market).

Anyhow, the reason that I liked this place was because I went on my first online dating meet-up here. I got there early to ease my nerves and was able to work a abort-mission plan. If I switched from beer to vodka soda, it meant I wanted a soda and the check. She was more than game and just a pleasure. Though the intended companion was far from ideal, the bartender really help make this place stand out as a "must frequent."
author: Leslie T.

description:
Life is all about balance.  For example, this morning I received the Employee of the Quarter award at work, but the only reason I was there to receive it was because I forgot about a jury summons, my group was called, and I consequently received a failure to appear.

Irish car bombs are about balance, too.  It's cool to chug them faster than your friends, but not-so-cool to throw them back up on the bar (sorry Elbo Room).

Sundays at Lone Palm are unofficial Irish Car bomb competition days.  So sit back in one of the comfy seats and drink your liquid courage with your buddies until you're ready to challenge the gorgeous gal behind the bar.  They say she's undefeated and will buy you a drink if you win. 

I came here on a Monday, but I'll be back on a Sunday.

Try not to puke on the bar, but if you do, then there are free snacks on the tables and rosewater in the bathroom to help reclaim your feminine scent (Hi, mom!)
author: Janney B.

description:
Really nice joint. Quiet, clean, great place for a drink.
Screw Regina from NYC- dogs in bars rule. Extra star.
author: Jonny A.

description: One of my favorite bars in the Mission, it's even kinda classy, well classy for a bar. It's a good pre or post dinner drink place to go with your significant other.
author: Sheila T.

description:
Always playing 80s music and the bar is lit with neon -- is it a throwback, or was it contemporary two decades ago and stuck to its formula until it became popular again?

White table clothes, a crowd in the 30s and 40s -- for that next stage in your life.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Great place to do some quality day drinking. The bartender was accommodating and nice. It was a little bit like a magical cocoon where you can lose sense of time and place. Offered great free snacks.
author: Libby O.

description:
At first glance and in the daylight, it appears to be a complete dive bar.  So not true.  LP is a great neighborhood lounge, with a great ambiance, kind, competent bartenders and listenable music. The drinks are a little pricey and incredibly inconsistent in strength.  The candles on the tables were a nice touch and the crowd was friendly and fun.

Update:  The last couple of times I went there caused me to dub this place the Lone Palmolive - the glasses always taste like dish soap!  Either that or their tonic water is funky.  Beware the Lone Palmolive....
author: Molly B.

description:
Simply put, Lone Palm is a classic spot.

They have candles, white table cloths and ... peanuts! And, to top it off, it's a mellow friendly bunch. It's a reliable spot to go with friends.
author: Sarah T.

description:
If you want to see a lone bartendress working her camisole off behind a long bar, with 18" round surprisingly white-tableclothed tables, packed close, with one each of  two different types of fake palms stalking the corners, and a cool floor stand mirror to do a clothing and makeup check near the front door as you make your way to the next location for the night (Esperpento in our case)...

Lone Palm is your place, baby!
author: Tamar D.

description:
OK, so this place sort of kicks ass. Its a really hard one to describe.

You'd think a place called "lone palm" with a single palm tree out front in a zit-on-your-ass area of the mission (a place you don't normally look) with a neon pink sign would scream sketch dive bar hell. 
However, on entering the place, you've got white tablecloths, and carpet, and a really really hot bartender from somewhere in europe against a pretty stocked bar. Very James Bond.

Actually, that above contradiction sort of sums up this bar. I mean, they are just everywhere: TVs are playing old skool black and white movies. The soundtrack is chill music, but all over the map from trip hop to beck. You've got candlelit tables, but graffiti-ed restrooms (I think?). All the crazy contradictory input confuses my brain, but I just can't help but love the shit out of it. Oh yeah, the stiff pours for reasonable prices help to confuse my brain too.

Just go to this place. You'll totally fit right into the contradiction: you'll feel like a secret agent even though you're in a hoodie and jeans.
author: Sean C.

description:
Tip well friends. Because that very well made gin and tonic you'll be enjoying in this "dive with class" is only going to set you back $4.50*. There is a neon sign outside and candle lit tables inside. Patrons include lively groups of friends and couples deep in conversation. It's a bar for all occasions with drinks that tend to make those occasions better.

One of my favorite spots for a drink.

*Quote attributed to the rather articulate yelper Jeremy G.
author: Jason B.

description: One of my favorite places for a cocktail. A little crowded and loud, but reasonable prices for solid drinks. The white table cloths really elevate the experience.
author: Juls M.

description:
Watch out for the bar. it's got this rail on the edge of it to keep spills from landing on your lap... but when you unwittingly place your completely-full glass of tequilla and lime on it, the whole thing will topple.  I saw some people learn this the hard way.  But they also learned that if they complain consistently and loudly enough, eventually they will be gifted a new tequilla and lime.  But look out anyway, its a bummer.

Chill with friends, or have a quiet drink with an attractive member of the opposite [or same] sex. You're not going to get too rowdy here, you're not going to watch the game, and you're not going to dance.  I'd say its a good starting up bar.
author: Mari C.

description:
Perhaps I should give this bar 3 stars, on account of the fact that, not too long after exiting its premises and taking a bus from the Mission to Potrero Hill, I found myself face-down on the sexy San Francisco cement, a victim of mild drunkenness and goddamn motherfucking uneven pavement. Yes, I got a fat lip. Yes, I scraped my hands and bruised my knee. Yet I am still giving the Lone Palm 4 stars? Your guess is as good as mine. 

I never would have entered--or probably even heard of--this bar had I not been walking up towards Guerrero on a creme brulee mission. However, mission accomplished, I spot this unimposing, divey-looking bar and immediately told my friend that we were entering. And enter we did. What greeted us was a surprisingly nice-looking bar, complete with white cloth-covered tables with candles and individual bowls of snacky foods (which had just been put out, so I munched on mine without worry of semen and fecal matter). 

It was relatively dark and very chill, and there were two adorable and friendly dogs in the bar. Any bar that allows dogs scores points with me. I don't much remember the alcohol choices, but suffice it to say that there's a full bar (obviously) and a decent selection of beer on tap (by decent I mean that you can actually get Stella if you want, not just crappy American brews, though I'm pretty sure that those are on draft too). Not too expensive but not too cheap either, and definitely a relaxed atmosphere for having a drink (or more) in the company of friends or unimposing and friendly regulars. 

Due to its location up by the corner of 22nd and Guerrero, this isn't really in the part of the Mission I usually hang out in, so I probably won't be at Lone Palm except on very rare occasions, but I'm happy to know that I've discovered a "new," clean bar at which to have the occasional drink. Maybe after the next time I eat at Papalote?

Oh yes. That sounds like a plan.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I feel like I've just stepped into a film noir.

Everyone looks so nice by candlelight. 

Make mine a whisky sour.

"Get me to that bus stop and forget you ever saw me. If we don't make it to the bus stop... "

Carry me home.
author: Melanie B.

description:
Great bar for friends to get together, drink, and catch up before going out on the town. 
Off the main mission strip area, so somewhat less people but get there earlier if you want to find a nice little table to sit at with your friends.
author: Alicia W.

description:
I don't know what's going on with the interior of this place. I can't decide if it's Art Deco with the lights and the script, Egyptian with the reliefs on the wall, or what. It still looked pretty cool despite the conflicting styles. Fairly cool.

The one thing that really bummed me out was the bathrooms. It reminded me of going into the Elephant House at the Cincinnati Zoo during the dog days of summer. It's by far the stinkiest commode I've visited in San Francisco.

And they were out of their beer special, which made me feel very unspecial.
author: Corbin C.

description:
This place has an odd Miami Vice vibe going on, like it was a leftover set from the show stuck in the '80s. But that's not exactly a knock. I like it. I like that dogs can hang out and roam, and that there's snacks on each table (jalapeño potato chips!), and that each table has tablecloths and candles. And a sexy bartenderess.

And with all that class, beer is just $4.50. Love it.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
We just had our Holiday Party at the Lone Palm last night and it was fricking AWESOME! Every single person that works at the Lone Palm is fricking rock star. From the owner to the doorman to the wonderful Ginger, all great people. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Chris G.

description:
We were out and about in the mission last night and were in need of a chill place to sip a few drinks and catch up amongst friends.  Luckily, our oasis, Lone Palm, was right around the corner from our dinner spot.  

Totally enjoyed hanging out here.  Patrons were normal/cool, the bar wasnt crowded and table seating was easy to find.  Music was decent and the bartender had some spunk.  She was kind enough to cancel our cc bill and rerun it so that we could split it amongst more of us.  But make sure you leave at 2am, otherwise you'll get yelled at by the bouncer for ruining his night.

Can't wait to hit happy hour here.  If I keep finding places like this in the mission, dare I say it, I may need to move to that part of town. :)
author: samit P.

description:
The white table cloths and candles tell a story. 

This is a place for intimate conversations, for falling in love, and for chilling out with people you like.

I came in on a recon mission, I wanted to see if this place would be suitable for one of the social events I've been organizing. It wouldn't be but it's still a place I'd come back to someday.

They don't seem to have any happy hour deal. The bartender did her job but wasn't particularly friendly. The clientele seems like a mixture of neighborhood people and Mission chodes with full beards and beanies. I did like the friendly dogs.
author: Manny F.

description:
Came here on a tuesday afternood after I picked up a friend from the airport. She wanted a drink, so we decided to look for a place with happy hour. 

Thank god for the yelp iphone app. I was around the mission and lone palm popped up.

When you walk up it looks a little sketch, with a pink neon sign. But then you walk in see the full bar, white table clothed tables and you feel much better. Then you sit at the bar and order yourself a drink. The bartender was a cool lady, happy hour was a $1 off any drink, which was nice.

At first there weren't that many people, but after an hour it got a good crowd going. The one bad thing was that it seemed the music got louder as more people came in, that was pretty annoying. It reached a point where we were literally yelling at each other and saying "Huh? What?" But other than that its a chill place. I'll most likely be coming back.
author: Paula I.

description: Our crews favorite happy hour place hands down. Great atmosphere, great drinks, amazing people. Give it a shot - u won't regret it.
author: Robyn P.

description:
There are bars, and there are bars where memories happen.  The Lone Palm is one of the latter.

It's very classic:  tables with tablecloths, attractive low lighting, plenty of stools, great bartenders, and strong drinks - all good.  There is history here - it used to be a tranny hangout.
