It has sort of an "old SF" feeling and is a happy change from the youth-infested bars in the Mission.  It would be easy to be a regular here.

There was a "falling down" incident in my group of friends on Saturday night.  Instead of being a faux pas, it was a beautiful, hilarious moment in a great night.  That's the kind of place the Lone Palm is - you can fall down and get right up again, and be no worse for the wear.
author: Liz S.

description: Lone Palm is a good neighborhood bar. I love that it's off the beaten path and therefore quieter than everything on Valencia and Mission, and the bartenders are friendly and competent. Stop in for a drink sometime, you won't regret it.
author: Sam K.

description:
I first came to know of the Lone Palm when the Mythbusters called it out as one of their favorite joints in their Weekly Yelp interview. Without that, I could have continued living merely blocks away without ever thinking of entering. I finally did though and had a decent experience. Nothing all that memorable, except for the wide range - and I mean wide, like the ocean - of music and white table clothes. I couldn't piece together any particular logic or theme to the place but maybe that's the point. Seemed like your basic, run-of-the-mill Mission bar.

Interesting note... I just checked out their website and they describe themselves as "an elegant, comfortable lounge filled with warm music and candlelight." The description goes on to say they are located in the "most sophisticated section" of the Mission. Now I am just plain baffled.
author: Susan L.

description:
Went here after having an awful experience at Latin American Club (http://www.yelp.com/biz/latin-american-club-san-francisco#hrid:i46dn9HIV2D_tDV0F0YKuQ).

This place has a very interesting feel to it...linen tablecloths, classy candles on the tables, but always at least one dog in there. Not quite sure what to make of it yet...but I know I like it.

Full bar, liquor wine and beer, great service, it's a solid little neighborhood bar to go chill out at.
author: John S.

description: I liked the candles on the white linen tables.  It's a nice touch.  They have Hoegaarden on tap.  Standard Mission dive bar, but with that classy touch.  I have heard corporate lawyers would prefer the sports bar across the street.  Thankfully, I am not corporate lawyer.  I prefer Lone Palm as a watering hole.
author: Jeremy G.

description: This might be the perfect Mission bar for someone who avoids hipsters and dancing and Top 40 loud decibels. I'm not willing to commit to that statement sans "might" yet, but I do know that I fully intend to return to this Miami Vice-esque (can't take credit for that comparison, my friend came up with it) cave to solidify my statement. I came here with a group for a friend's birthday, and even though it was very crowded, we still managed to find space in the back and no one was angry if we occasionally bumped into them. It's a happy, dank little oasis, with nice bartenders and kitschy decorations and, okay, white tablecloth'd tables? Classy. Mission, things are looking up for you.
author: Stefanie L.

description: Ughh. Just walked by there the other night, considering walking in, and saw that the same awful pixie woman bartender was there who ignored me (and apparently others). Can't management get thier act together and get some decent bartenders in there?
author: Jeff R.

description:
OK, this is my neighborhood watering hole.  OK, I've only been in the neighborhood for a few months, but this is the place I like the most.  It's quite mellow (well, compared to, say, the Latin American club down the street), and the bartenders are quite nice, and occasionally, there's a friendly dog that hangs out there, too.  A friend of mine introduced me to it when I was looking for a mellow place to memorialize a loved one's death by raising a glass of spirited beverage, and she thought that this would be the place, and it worked out well for me that night.

It's the type of place I can go to by myself or with friends and hang out.  The clientele is cool, too -- at least on a couple of occasions when I was there, I've been able to have some rockin' conversations with some sharp, interesting folks (one time, about polymerase chain reaction, wtf!), or the time I got invited to join a new year's pub crawl by a group travelling through.  Ah, fun times!
author: Ken Y.

description:
I've been to the Lone Palm a couple of times and always seem to enjoy myself but this past Saturday I couldn't help but notice that my drinks tasted, eh, kind of nasty. I ordered Stoli/soda three times and all three drinks tasted differently. 

We got all Sherlock Holmesian and tried to figure out what was wrong. Bad ice? Flat soda water? Our conclusion - dish washing soap. 

Did we complain? No. 
Did we stop and switch to beer? No. 
Did I still have a great time? Yes. 
Will I be drinking bottled beer next time I go to the Lone Palm? That's elementary, my dear Watson.
author: phil h.

description:
My first experience with the Lone Palm was an odd mix.  In the end, it won me over.

I walked in and immediately felt like throwing up.  The place was completely packed and there was just some odd aroma of people that made me nearly lose my dinner.

Once I'd had a drink, and the crowd started to thin a little, I realized this is actually a pretty cool place.  The seating is plentiful, the patrons friendly, the bartenders were just gems, and the drinks were...whatever, the drinks were acceptable.

I'm sort of new to San Francisco.  I mean, I've lived here for three years, but I feel like I'm still just discovering it.  So one of my favorite things to do, one of my favorite experiences, is being out on the town and running into friends.  Makes you feel like you're home.  Well it turns out Lone Palm is a favorite haunt of an old group of friends of mine, so an extra star is due for being a friendly meeting place.
author: Oliver N.

description:
Very cool little out of the way bar, with interesting lighting, art and an excellent sound system playing some very cool, mostly old acoustic music on a rainy Friday afternoon. This place could easily be just another dive bar in the Mission, but some creative soul has transformed it - as much as possible - into almost a classy little lounge. And by almost, I mean not really.   There is a nice assortment of high and low tables, with white tablecloths and candles glowing.  Really quite lovely.  

This place has to lose a star for its unfriendly bartender.  The only customers in the entire bar, she let us just sit at one of these lovely tables for 10 minutes or so, until finally yelling over to us, "If you want a drink YOU are going to have to come see ME."  Ok, sure bitch.  You're a barTENDER, not a barMAID.  I get it now.  Except the only thing you were tending was that misanthropic snarl on your face.  Sorry if your new tattoo is crooked.  Don't take it out on me. I just want a drink.  

Here's another tip, faux Mission hipster:  If you have a chalkboard upon which you write an assortment of various wines, don't sneer and chuckle to yourself when a customer orders a Zinfandel.  

I'm going back anyway.  I like the feel of this place.  With a bunch of other people in here, I am sure the negativity from behind the bar will nicely dissipate before arriving at my table.
author: Jay Z.

description:
I mean, what do you even say that does justice to the Lone Palm?? The bartenders are gorgeous and sexy, the interior elements are gorgeous and sexy, and Hangar One Mandarin Blossom and soda with a splash of cran? Gorgeous and sexy. There's nary an aspect of the Lone Palm that hasn't been fawned upon. 

So let's just talk about the ladies' room. This is not a bathroom, or a restroom, or a latrine. This is a LADIES' room. It's not so much a bar bathroom as it is a quiet respite from a gauche world. The kind of place where a lady takes a step back and regains her composure.

So, not only is the Ladies' Room at the Lone Palm a lovely place to be, it's a lovely place to wash hands, which is usually a challenge in bar bathrooms. But Lone Palm has a brushed nickel faucet with excellent water pressure, a basket of loose paper towels (now, that's class), a bottle of hand lotion, and a refreshing body spray. And the bottle of hand lotion is usually Caldrea's Rose Tobacco scent. It's an unusual scent, but a beautiful one. 

The kind of scent that, combined with the sultry atmosphere, and perhaps Arcade Fire's "Neighborhood #1 (Tunnels)" on the sound system, creates a transportative, almost supernatural moment in time. "Sometimes, we remember bedrooms...our parent's bedrooms, and the bedrooms of our friends." Indeed.
author: Megan W.

description:
Lone Palm, I just wanted to say... 

I'm sorry I haven't patronized you more. Especially while living two blocks away. Crikey. I really have no excuse, except maybe I'm intimidated by how CIVILIZED the people in you seem to behave. Because overall, I end up acting like an ass when I go out to an establishment that solely serves alcohol. About 90% of the time. I'm not even going to try to pretend otherwise. Read my, like, 230 some other reviews. 

But lately I've had a hankering to behave in a more civilized manner while imbibing (as evidenced by the very civilized tone of this review). You know -- like sit at a cozy table in a dimly lit, chill bar with good service and NOT get trashed. Maybe just sip on the same quality drinky-drink for a while with a friend or two and have intelligent conversation...

That's what people do in you and -- it's not bad. I can do it (okay, maybe the intelligent conversation part is pushing it...). I can even write a review like this. No one will UFC it, but that's a risk I'm willing to take to show you how serious I am.

Aren't you impressed? 

Thanks for taking credit cards, too. That's what really forced me to take the plunge...
author: Lisa T.

description:
Is it tablecloths that make this place a lounge? Every time I've been here I've seen some drunk start a fire with the Lone Palm's idiotic table cloths. THEY DON'T SERVE FOOD! There is no cocktail service! It's not A RIB JOINT! I suspect that the unfortunate tablecloths are just useless beards for the LPs homely tables. I care not.

[[SF/X Jon Bon Jovi - Blaze Of Glory]]

~ The only thing I do care about this place is that they have Stella on tap and a draft cider, so I can get my precious Snakebites. 
~ The bartenders here are good. You can get a decent mixed drink. 
~ And the place looks cuh-lassy. But it's soul that counts.

Here's what's unfortunate. It's NEARLY ALWAYS a mistake to let the bartender pick the music, and this is that kind of place. No juke box. Hence, the music sucks. It sucks, it sucks, it sucks DOGGY BONE! Plus it's a tiny place that gets SMOOSHED with people on weekends, all screaming over the dreadful and loud. I swear every time I've been here on a weekend it's been SOMEONE'S boring-ass birthday party. A sardine can that pipes deadly dull music AT EAR-SPLITTING VOLUME with pointless...oog...plain white tablecloths. How grand. Let's spend MY birthday here please. The year AFTER I die.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Seeing as every review of this place calls it romantic or a great first date spot you would expect that you would walk in and see couples hiding in the corners, their martinis casually cast aside in favor of some good old fashioned, innocent, drunken smooching. I mean, aside from the sometimes poor taste in the music they play, this place has character and class for being a hole in the wall bar on a quiet street in the Mission. They even have tablecloths, for goodness sake. 

Alas, no. Not a single person making out at their candlelit table. More importantly, not a single person drinking a martini. The latter I REALLY don't get. This bar is art deco. That in and of itself nearly demands that some martinis be ordered. I guarantee they would be good, the bartenders make some mighty fine drinks at this place. Plus, martinis are strong, thus taking away that awkwardness you might be feeling as you approach the night cap portion of your date. 

Yes, I like this place, but it will not get 5 stars until someone takes me here, orders me a Sapphire martini (dirty) and cozies up with me in a dark corner. Oh, and this can only take place on a weekday because, as with most SF bars, its way too crowded on the weekend.
author: Drue C.

description:
What a cool little joint.

So yesterday on my mini bar crawl tour of SF, my new friend and I came here to throw back a few. The place was empty, but luckily for us the bartender was a cool chicky and kept us entertained and even let me sniff bottles. Hey, we all have our things! 

I would definitely come back here again at night to check out the scene in it's true bumpin form, but until then, I will keep it high on the list of cool little dive bars to waste the day away at :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
This is where professional bartenders and professional drinkers put in WORK.
I'm out of my depth here as I run a 24 hour service and don't want to be .085 +, but if I said "fuck it, fuck 'em!" Then this would be the place to lose my soul.
Like a well produced porn, it's totally nasty yet hard to ignore...
It also serves as an office of sorts to a good friend of mine.
They seem to treat him well.
I thank them for that, and it is nice to always know where he is.
All kidding aside, there's little b.s. here. 
Just good old fashion drinkin'.
author: Theo R.

description:
It looks pretty divey but they have white linen table cloths and rose water in the bathroom.  That's pretty damn classy to me.  They also had free food the night I was there.  I didn't eat it and I don't know what the occasion was or where it came from but an announcement was made.  I thought that was generous.

They had all the whiskeys and vodkas I like and a decent selection of beers on tap.  There were a good number of tables and bar seats so a big group could fit in nicely.

They also didn't care when someone tried to be a magician by pulling a table cloth off one of the tables while sending a candle straight to the floor.  Ta-da!
author: Seong P.

description:
San Francisco is thousands and thousands of Lone Palms..  
Thirtysomethings masquerading as Twentysomethings, sending smoke signals to the other desert palms, waiting for a ship to rescue them and carry them to harbor, or for a storm to come and wash them away.
Enjoy every drop at the Lone Palm.
author: Patrick A.

description: Bartenders were very cool to us. It reminds me a lot of the other bars I like in San Francisco that harken back to an era where people smoked in office buildings and men drank bourbon, not wine coolers. The sort of place where it's OK to be thirty, even preferable. May it never attract hipsters.
author: Neal P.

description:
A refreshing break from the formulaic irony-laden hipster bars in the vicinity - no ironic black velvet paintings or stuffed mooseheads in sight. Just a sexy noirish classic Miami/LA vibe and good classic drinks. The place to wear pencil skirts, seamed stockings, something filmy. Weekends can get a little crazy crowded, but weekdays nights are just sublime.

Order yourself a vodka gimlet, gracefully sidle into one of the booths or tables laden with white tablecloths, Then watch the door for your rendezvous with that mysterious stranger. The one you met emerging from the fog while you were walking down that San Francisco street, heels clicking on the pavement, echoes into the cold city night. 

Yeah, it's that kind of place.
author: Umami Y.

description:
In the 90's my style was 75% Cuban grandpa which lends itself to the 40's noir style of this spot. The Lone Palm was also the last place I fell asleep standing up. Actually, to be truthful it was more like passed out but that story would take more that 5000 characters.
This place is perfect for adult drinks and adult conversations. I first met my own personal Yelp Elite here and I couldn't have asked for a better introduction to the community so it automatically gets five stars.
author: Mingus R.

description:
With so many amazing Yelpers hanging here, how could it not be cool?

Some work friends brought  me here to blow of steam from a project that has temporarily gone to 'heck in a heck basket'. It was pretty early on a Thurs eve (say oh, 5pm on the dot) and the place was pretty empty except for the bartender and the adorable dog. 

The bartender was cute, friendly and very good at mixing a drink, or two, or three, or, ok  lets face it I think I had five vodkas and soda (it could have been six). And, I have to say, she was very gracious when I grabbed back my pretty much empty fifth glass to get that last little drop. She also didn't even frown when I went around collecting the various bowls of munchies from empty tables because variety IS the spice of life, and she even smiled when I added baby carrots to one we emptied (you know, Weight Watchers). So all in all we had a great time without feeling the bartender hated us, although I honestly wouldn't blame her if she isn't my biggest fan. Maybe I should go back and tip her again.

I really like those bowls of munchies. And the dog, although I got a little tired of playing catch. Well, really I just started to suck at it around drink 4.
author: Lise L.

description: Went to Lone Palm at 6:00 on a Sunday and the bar was completely empty, which I didn't mind. What I did mind was my drink which was honestly the worst Manhattan I have ever had in my life.  The bartender made me suspicious when she commented on the fact that she didn't like Bulleit, which in my opinion is an excellent bourbon.  The drink tasted like cough medicine and was difficult to swallow without wincing.  $10 down the tubes.  The atmosphere is fun--Casablanca meets Miami Vice--but if you go, do NOT order a Manhattan.
author: Lydia B.

description:
So we were walking up 22nd to get a drink on Valencia when I run into a friend I haven't seen since in a bit. 

Dae: Hey what's up, you want to get a drink and catch up?  
Me: Ummm....points at other shadowy figure standing behind me. 
Dae: oh...date night. 
Me: something like that. 
Dae: Where are you going? Actually, it doesn't even matter -- you are going to the Lone Palm.
Me: The place up the street? Might as well call it Red Palm because that's what I'll have after taking someone there and being sent home alone....looks like a crappy dive bar.


So off we go in blind faith in Dae.. before we even get to decor.....the best thing about this place is the crowd it draws. Everything from polo shirts and pinstripes to piercings and tats -- that's my type of bar.  This is definitely NOT a dive bar.  White linen over tables with candles --- but not in a foo foo kind of way but more like just a relaxed and comfortable place to hang out over a drink.

Drinks are strong and cheap and the bartender was very friendly. 

I'm suprised it took me so long to find this spot since I'm always over here with friends living up and down 22nd. 

4 very solid stars for this spot. Dae I owe you buddy.
author: Morgan H.

description:
I watched the chick behind the bar pour my drink, so I do know she at least attempted to get some sort of alcohol in there. Funny when I tasted it there was no liquor. Not "no" as in "a little," but "no" as in "absolutely nothing." I even did a taste test and five out of five said "wow, that's the shittiest tasting soda and soda drink ever." When informing her that there seemed to be some mistake, as she splashed some Citron on top (which when sipped again still tasted like stale cigarette water, go figure, there's no liquor in the bottle) the bitch says to me "if you want straight vodka order a shot." Well, I'm a bitch, too, and let's say that didn't go over very well. 

Bottom line: if you go to this somewhat of a shithole that employs nasty bartenders (you know who you are), don't bother to order anything with Citron - someone's clearly pouring backwash into the bottle.
author: petals o.

description:
Sometimes, all I need in life is a quick and kind bartender, an ice cold sidecar, some low lights, and a couple drinking buddies with whom to share the gossip and war stories of the week.  Lone Palm is such a place.

MInus one star for the ill conceived text messages said sidecars caused me to send before the night was done.  Hardly the fault of the LP but no one said life was fair kiddies.
author: Pammy C.

description:
Are you in the mood to visit a low-key, unpretentious bar with funky decor and affordable drinks? Then take thy alcoholic self to the Lone Palm and prepare to enjoy a pleasant trip to inebriationville...

I recently went here on a Friday and there were several tables available, which is rare for a bar in the Mission (or at least I think it is). A few $4.00 vodka and sodas later, and I'm almost tempted to nosh on the free peanuts...however, I know better thanks to an experience I had hanging with a hypochondriac friend during a vacation back in '03...I learned more about bar snacks and urea counts than a human being needs to know! Totally ruined the fun I used to have shoveling handfuls of peanuts into my drunken mouth and then licking the bottom of the snack bowl clean...kidding!

Okay,back to the bar...I love the dark atmosphere and retro feel of this place, the bartender was really cool and the drink prices can't be beat...plus, it's somewhat off the beaten path in the Mission, so it's not as crowded as the usual haunts...

Enjoy a night with...oops, I mean at the Lone Palm sometime!
author: Art D.

description:
I am not 100% sure what is up with the white tablecloth vibe, but I definitely liked Lone Palm.

Masturbation jokes aside, the place is a good place to bring a date.  Its quiet, the drinks are strong, and they have snack food.

Basically, its Martuni's light for people who can't handle the gay -piano bar fabulousness.  

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Steve S.

description:
On a typical Saturday. 
We had drinks at Lone Palm. 
The set up: a tall bar, several round tables with white dressings. 

This place has got romance. 

So why did my stomach feel like an uneasy bucket? 
Affected by no one else but Nick. 

Remember Nick?

I felt that low-low, pit-bottom sadness. 
But I was glad to see him. Nick and his sharp smile-- charming, purposeful. Still made me blush.

"What's so great about San Francisco anymore? There's all the same people at these tired bars," he said.
"Go back to Brooklyn then. This city doesn't need another critic, let alone another writer," I said. 

At the bar. The lighting's a stale orange. The right kind of mood. It seemed just fine for ladies to have either cocktail or beer, for gents to sit in wide stances-- comfortably, with whichever drink. 

I prefer scotch.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Huh, how have I not reviewed the LP yet?

This one will be short. 
This is the bar I am looking to retire and eventually die in. (See Eddie Rickenbaker review)

It's perfect.
author: Melissa H.

description:
i've always loved this place.  since 2005, this has been my go to bar.  however, not until recently did i discover that Jamie makes the greatest negroni i have ever had.  

do yourself a favor and order the negroni if Jamie is working.
author: Helpful S.

description:
Too many wonderful, terrible things have gone down at that one little tucked-into-a-corner hightop round table.  Like handjobs.

Ginger pours the best Plymouth gin and tonic.  Everything else has been said.  Wear stockings, bring drama, leave it under the table in some dreamy guy's hands, and go.
author: Melissa G.

description: Yelp had directed me elsewhere, so I passed this place on the way to go somewhere else.  As others have noted, the neon sign out front is really eye-catching, so I resolved to hit this place up on my way back.  I'm really glad I did!  This is just the kind of cocktail lounge where you'd expect to find some characters from a David Lynch film.  Low lighting, candles, small tables and an expansive but intimate bar.  As for the margaritas, truly delicious.  I wish I had a place like this in my hood (but then I might have to go to AA.)
author: Matthew B.

description: Great vibe, great diversity of people, great lady bartenders (on Fridays at least) and a nice spot to plant yourself if you're looking for an anonymous type of place (i.e. date or business drinks). I like sitting in the corner and having a giant lone palm leaf dangle over my head. Makes me feel like being a monkey; I just want to climb up the tree and stare at all the interesting peeps that flock.
author: Meredith R.

description: Back in the early to mid 1990's this was THE place to sit at the bar and sweat the drugs out of your system while nursing cocktails. God Bless You, Lone Palm.
author: Alan P.

description:
Wouldn't go out of my way for it. I haven't seen it turn into a full-on chodefest like others have, but I still don't have much reason to come very often.

Art Deco South Beach-y decor is interesting, but I don't know who thought long tablecloths in a place that serves alcohol was a good idea. The place does have a really nice atmosphere reminiscent of some old-school Miami Vice/Havana joint, but, for me, it just didn't quite reach its potential.
author: Tara R.

description:
I left this bar unimpressed.  I suppose I should've predicted that from the beginning.  I got to the bar first and my friends were running a bit late.  I hung out outside and a local befriended me.  She told me that there was a creepy dude inside and advised me not to go it alone, since my friends weren't around.  She was nice enough to invite me to Liberties with her.

It was definitely a sausage fest when I walked in.  It wasn't difficult to spot my friends because they were the group in the back, near the restroom, with 2 women at the table.  I didn't have any issues ordering my drink, but the place is more divey than the Hi-Dive.  

The women's restroom backed up and my friend had to use the Men's restroom.  After we let the bartender know of the problem, she promptly grabbed a plunger from the closet and got to work...  That was our signal to leave because she was the only employee in that place.  First she was serving drinks then she was plunging the toilet.
author: Annalynn C.

description: Met up with a friend here last night and was pretty pleased with the service. Had not been here in a looooong time. I ordered a Manhattan and let the bartender choose the whiskey because I observed her being extremely helpful with others re: their "special" orders... She delivered perfectly, and with a smile and courteous explanation of why she chose the special rye she did. Kept the goldfish bowl filled, too. Reading some of the more draconian entries here, I have to conclude that perhaps those who had bad experiences simply had the wrong server. Our girl rocked.
author: Ben W.

description:
I'll have to agree with the previous reviewer's comment about Phillip K. Dick and this bar: it has a just slightly "off" feel to it, in a dark, yet good way.

Its dark, but not too dark: your table lit by a small tea candle.  The music is loud, but the seating is such that you can hear your date.  The decor is Art Deco-ish with a touch of the surreal.

Watch out though, the white table cloths will throw you the first time you come by.  You will think you are in some kind of upscale pretentious establishment...  Then you will see the James Cagney gangster flick silently playing on the television, order your sanely-priced beverage, and settle in for a nice evening with a cute date.

One last thing: don't sit at the tall tables, you slide out of the chairs.
author: Shane L.

description:
They have white tablecloths here, which tells you all you need to know about the atmosphere--mellow and sophisticated (but, gratefully, not pretentious).  

Just be careful when standing up that said white tablecloth is not caught in your belt or pants or anything so that when you turn to go to the bathroom you don't pull the whole mess of drinks and candles down upon you in a mortifying clatter of drunken clumsiness and everyone tries not to laugh but does anyway and you go hide in the bathroom for awhile and then come back and try to play it off by saying something like "hey guys, what'd I miss?"

(This of course, is just a hypothetical situation and in no way, shape or form represents anything that actually happened to me...)
author: Kevin H.

description:
As mentioned in other reviews, I do not like bars.  I do not like paying more money to drink in a place where I can't talk to the people I am with and I can't control the volume or content of the music.  What I'm trying to say is, I'm an old man at heart.  But occasionally it is a pertinent decision one has to make - you can't always drink in your kitchen, and people watching isn't the worst activity to partake in when you're downing high alcohol content beverages.

This place used to be super close to me, so to kill an hour, it was a place to pop in and have a Boont and watch in horror as Noe Valley balding professionals met the past their prime Mission hipster chicks.  I'm pretty bar-naive, but do most bars share a similar dynamic?  That sucks.
author: Mike A.

description:
Many subtle details go into making the Lone Palm a 4-star spot. First, it definitely qualifies as a LOUNGE, not just another bar. For the gentlemen and scholars who prefer to sip their Old Fashioneds comfortably seated at tables covered in fine white linen, as opposed to bumping elbows with a bunch of light-beer drinking louts, this is not an overlooked nicety.

There are coat-hooks under the bar, bottomless snacks,  and the words "bro," "bitches," and "chug" are seldom encountered. The dimly lit interior, accented with teal and pink fluorescent light, creates the kind of retro-feel that's not trying-to-be, rather just is. A bit off the beaten path of other Mission establishments, the Lone Palm is a true oasis of class for the discerning partaker of San Francisco nightlife.
author: Chris P.

description: Very Miami Vice theme going on. Small, intimate tables--looks like a jazz lounge, but I didn't see a stage. Beers were a good price, I think $3.50 for a Stella. I will come back when I want a more romantic kind of evening and see how I feel about it then.
author: Shira O.

description:
I stumbled upon this place with some friends after dinner and was not impressed by the dog who kept sniffing the cookies I had bought and the smoke that drifted in from outside.  The place was dark and 70s decor added a surreal touch to the place.  Mainly, I was shocked by the persistent dog.  
The bartender was patient and created a cucumber vodka drink for my friend which was refreshing.
author: Regina C.

description: What a great little neighborhood bar.  It looks pretty ho-hum when you pass it by on the street but once you venture inside, it's got a nice little cafe/bar feel.  A bit fancy with table cloths and candles on the tables and a few high tables along the walls but the atmosphere is casual and fun.  Drinks are a bit of an after thought as I believe they provide more of a great locale for chatting and enjoying the good company of friends.
author: Karen N.

description:
My last visit was an extremely crowded Saturday night with some pals. The scotch we ordered was some of the most paltry pours I've ever paid for outside of a ball park with those auto-narc pour devices. I wondered if it was poured from one of those chump bottles you get on the plane. 

Bartenders - here's a quandary: on a busy Saturday night, why are you allowing 5-6 dudes with absolutely no game whatsoever to sit sucking up space at your bar nursing their PINTS OF BEER?!?!? I took a gander at them. They're not your boyfriends. They looked too cheap to be admirers; they would have purchased a shot to go with the Stella water. Boot 'em, send them to to the bodega to pick up a six, and get back to their XBox.

Anyway, I'll have to try a weeknight soon, as they accept plastic...
author: Rene D.

description:
A Hollywood dive bar in the Mission.

This place would be a perfect setting for a Gwen Stefani music video.  I picture her bursting into the bar from the bathroom area done up like Marilyn Monroe--diamonds, white dress--only she'd be a zombie and her eyes would be falling out, and there'd be worms.  The patrons would move the tables out of the way and everyone would linedance Thriller style.

It's been awhile since my art history classes, but the reliefs?  friezes?  on the wall give this place a great ambience.

And they've got Boont on tap.
author: Eric E.

description:
This is an exercpt from a previous review, which has never happened to me at the Lone Palm:

"Order yourself a vodka gimlet, gracefully sidle into one of the booths or tables laden with white tablecloths, then watch the door for your rendezvous with that mysterious stranger. The one you met emerging from the fog while you were walking down that San Francisco street, heels clicking on the pavement, echoes into the cold city night."

I don't claim to be a master of the rendezvous, and certainly never with a mysterious stranger emerging from fog.  Does a fog machine count?  I don't think I've even done that.  Usually she's just sitting at the bar.  

On a positive note, this is the closest bar to my house, and it's a pretty good one.  Decent but limited selection of beers on tap (Boont Amber is enough to get me through a night), dim-light and laid-back atmosphere, music selection varies from *mediocre* to *pretty awesome* depending on the bartenders in control, but it's never awful.  The ratio of men-to-women is often a little high for my tastes, but the crew of regulars along the bar always make for a good time.  Overall, one of my favorite bars in the Mission, and probably the best when you just want to have a drink and relax, but aren't up for a crazy night.  That is... unless your special stranger wanders in amidst the fog.
author: Joe K.

description: Great drinks, great atmosphere. If there'd been more than one person working behind the bar on Saturday it would have been a five, but worth the wait and that set the pace, I suppose.
author: Odette L.

description: great for drinks and catching up w/ friends in a lounge-y secret hideaway!
author: t L.

description:
I've been here five or six times over the last four years, and only last night did I notice that there is a large PALM TREE in front of the entrance.  Go figure.

I like this place.  Midcentury decor and lounge aesthetic, friendly bar staff, slightly fancy tablecloths, tea light candles, generous pours.  All make the place stand out from the Mission menagerie of neo-dives and upscale post-dot-com clubs. Quality liquor in a clean glass is fine with me.  If only they had more beers on tap.
author: Matt R.

description:
I saw the good reviews on yelp, and realized that this place was half-a-block away from my friends house. A few minutes later, the crew had agreed to the plan - which involved grabbing a few drinks and just hanging out, laid-back-style. I was thinking "weekday lounge plan".

Parking isn't nearly as bad as other places in the Mish, and I had the parking Gods smiling down on me when I realized the spot on the street right opposite the bar was vacant. Automatic plus for that.

Strolling in, I immediately realized that ranking the lone palm amongst the "lounge" category is some yelpers idea of a joke. I'd say "neighborhoody dive bar" is a better characterization - what with the cheap neon sign outside, the black drapes, the slanted mirrors on the walls and the 3 dimensional art. And the bartender appeared to be the *only* employee - which meant that serving a drink took her a good 10-15 minutes at a time. And since she was more interested in serving people closest to her, I was less than thrilled with the service. Also, plastic isn't taken here. Automatic minus one each for these two.

Fortunately the presence of the crew was a positive, so I didn't worry too much about the venue. It got a little more crowded towards the end, but as my friend remarked, it was a major sausage-fest in there after a while. And a lot of older "we live around here and walked" types, very few women. Minus one for that also.

The womens restroom was clogged and my friend had to use the mens, which caused some minor consternation to other male patrons and was the subject of much hilarity for us - but they deserve a minus one for this as well; specifically because the bartender on being told of the clog, busted out a plunger and got busy. I really hope she washed her hands after.

I really strongly doubt I'll be back here, unless the service is improved, the seating is made more comfortable, and the clientle gets better looking BEFORE the drinking commences.
author: Maxx L.

description:
I lived less than half a block from the Lone Palm for five months and somebody had to point it out to me - I had no clue it even existed.

And I am so glad it was pointed out and I went in and it rocked my world. The Lone Palm is a totally random, obscure, weird from the outside bar. Not really a dive - they have white linen-clad tables - it's just random!

They always play the sickest tunes, the drinks are so good and right up my alley (stiff as hell usually) and everyone that works there is super nice.
author: C P.

description:
I am a lone palm.

I used to really really really love this place , I dont hate it now by any means but it lost a something in the last few years. maybe its that you cant smoke inside anymore. maybe its because the bartenders arent usually as friendly as they used to be. I dont know I just have gotten to a point where I dont frequent it any longer. Ive tried a few times recently to go in but its been way too packed and I hate that feeling of claustrophobia(i lived thru the golden age of the arrow bar-NEVER AGAIN).
author: Lauren V.

description:
This spot is a bit out of the way over on 22nd. Since there isn't any thing night-life-ish nearby, that does a lot to minimize the Random Riff-Raff (tm) that walks in here. That's what everyone means by it is "grown up" ...aka, no drunk fraternal people humping or barfing on your leg!  

The tables are tall bar tables and the music has just the perfect amplitude for a decent conversation without hollering, best for catching up with that friend whose schedule frees up once every 4 months!
author: I. O.

description: The last conscious moments of my 30th birthday were in this nice looking bar (I guess a few flashes were in El Rio).  I have a friend who "won't go" here because he thinks it's too crowded with bridge and tunnel types, but that's just not true.  He's one of those "been in the Mission for 12 years" types.  Dogs allowed.
author: Jack M.

description: Best night ever... mellow, after dinning, we came here for night cabs. Very friendly service, quick coming drinks. For a early weekday's night, it's the spot where you can find a peace.
author: Flora F.

description:
Lone Palm!  

Yes! Finally!  A bar that serves stiff drinks and has some questionable clientelle, yet classes it up with white tablecloths!  It definitely walks the fine line between dive bar and classy joint.

I came here Saturday evening and thought that I had walked into a place that had just finished its dinner service.  Come to find out, no food is served here (although they do have bowls of Goldfish and peanuts scattered throughout the place).  

Really nice bartenders (Isle was working and MAN! she has some cool stories), strong drinks, cool atmosphere, great location, awesome, fun, etc etc you get the idea.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
You have to love a bar where the bartenders (both attractive women) wear lederhosen.  And for no apparent reason.  Sassy.

Good neighborhood bar.  Sleazy neon scares away the upscale people.  Hot damn.
author: Evan G.

description:
I really liked this place - aside from the fact that the demographic was obviously older than me and my crew.  

I went on a friends recommendation and was pleased with the art deco interior and tables to chat and cheap beer.... 

Not so pleased with the two pregnant women in the bar.  Not together, mind you... two separate pregnant women.  Not that pregnant women can't go out and have a good time even if they aren't drinking, but it made it even more obvious that the Lone Palm is for the 30+ indi crowd.  

I went on a Fri night so that may have been as "sceney" as it gets..... I did really like it though so I'll try it again, maybe on a week night.
author: Alice H.

description:
This is my favorite bar in SF.


I can't find anything to complain about whatsoever.... Everything in this place makes me feel at home... I might even say that I have never had a bad afternoon or night here.  It has it all:

*Great Bartenders
*Good regular patrons
*Nice bar seating
*Good seating for groups with table clothed tables
*Low light (mostly candles) for a nice romantic wooing
*Walking distance to my home

In retrospect, after that list there is just one thing that could be better, there is no jukebox here so you are going to get whatever the bartenders feel like playing.  Lucky for you most of them have good taste... although if you are having an up tempo night and one of the girls is having a 'I just got in a fight with my man' night you might get too much Elliot Smith.... if that is possible.
author: Thadd L.

description: Good drinks.  Quiet, neighborhood atmosphere.  Decent seating.  Sometimes you see a cute dog in the bar.  Great place to go with people you know and have some conversation.
author: Alex H.

description:
Great neighborhood bar!

Don't let the entryway fool you, past the curtain is not the wizard, but a quaint and classy bar that has white table cloths and candles which add to the ambiance.

I'll admit to a bit of a crush on Ginger - hey, who doesn't though?!

In spite of an often 2- or 3-deep mob at the small bar, the staff is quick, courteous and both patient and efficient.

An extra star for being a block and half from my condo!
author: Rich N.

description:
I like this bar. It's actually one of the few places in the mission where I could go with a date.

Not super crowded during the weekend nights, cheap drinks (3 vodka drinks for $17) and a nice atmosphere. A little candle on you 2 person table.
This place is cute.

Go there during the weekdays for a better experience !
author: Marc L.

description:
On the weekends this place has a lively and stylish Mission crowd. But, this place really earns its keep during the slower weekdays when this place becomes the best bar in town to hang out with friends or better yet, have a drink with an ex, get hopped up enough to make some bad decisions, and play a game of "ouch, ouch, you're on my hair."  The bartenders are also the coolest group of bartenders in all of SF.

******Update Spring 2007
I've got to dock this place a star. The service has gone downhill, and the prices have gone up.
author: Josh K.

description:
It looked like the tables were too close together, and yet they all comfortably seated at least three people;  The white tableclothes seemed like they'd be a problem at first glance, but they were quickly forgotten;  The crowd didn't appear to be my type, and yet but they didn't bother me at all;  The bartender was useless in answering my questions about their selection, and yet she was otherwise very attentive and nice.  

However, my friends weren't fans, and though this place worked for me when by all accounts it shouldn't have, it's not high on my list of places to go back to any time soon.
author: Bailey S.

description:
Fun place to grab a drink, but awfully crowded on a random Friday night. The scene is casual and very local Mission-esque. 

The decor is a trip. 3-D statues of women on the walls provides interesting conversation piece!
author: Lee H.

description: Went to Lone Palm with a friend on Saturday night for cocktails - we arrived around 8, sat at the bar, and by 9, the place was packed. The cocktails were strong - and two drinks and two glasses of wine cost us about $27 (before tip). As it got more crowded, it got louder (voices and music), but since the two of us were sitting at the bar, we were close enough that we could still hear each other. I wouldn't necessarily choose it as a place to hold a big party (although there was one that night), but for a drink with a friend and reconnecting with the pulse of nightlife, it does the job.
author: Esther K.

description:
beside having tastefully dubious name and a namesake lonely palm outside this place kicks ass.

Reason one, when piss drunk, I'm only couple of knee-bruises away from this home from here. compared to 5 knee-bruises from 500club or elbo room.

reason two, This place gives you what Elbo room doesn't - some elboroom and some.

reason three, Like someone said - its got style without pretensions and got strong drinks for great prices. No where else have I gotten my Tanquerey 10 on rocks for $6 and I'm talking about a tall ass tanq 10.

great to start off or end the night on.



And can't go wrong with tablecloth on the tables, damn that gets me everytime. makes the place soo
author: An u.

description:
It was chill, not too trendy friendly crowd.  
The male bartender was generous with the drinks :)
The dj wasn't doing that great of a job spinning.
If I were in the neighborhood, I'd be back if I needed to grab a low-key drink with a friend.
author: Nicky C.

description:
Lone Palm is my friend Calvin's nickname so I had to go inside.

This place gets packed and makes the air temp. a sweaty, B.O.-inducing 90 degrees. Was there music? I can't remember. Drinks were well blended. No Cover. Lots of squealy girls all around. Yada. Yada. Yada. *Yawn*
author: Esther K.

description:
The Lone Palm is a solid 4-star lounge. The joint has a classy -- but not pretentious -- vibe. The bartenders are friendly, and most have a solid grasp on the art of mixology. They make a fantastic Old Fashioned! I'm looking for perfect balance in a mixed drink, not a stiff pour.

I'm also a big fan of the bottomless snacks served up on the tables. Not just your standard stale bar pretzels either.

Great place to have a drink after work, before dinner or at the beginning of a night out in the Mission.
author: Trevar M.

description:
The Lone Palm is almost certainly one of my favorite San Francisco bars, mainly because it's a classy, quiet, and relaxing place to have a drink and actual conversation with friends.  It's really small, so it does get crowded occasionally, but it's far enough off the beaten path that the partying hordes don't find it.

Oh, and I have a good story about it.  Ask me sometime.
author: Buzz A.

description:
From our rooms we can hear everyone leaving the Lone Palm, so we had to check it out. It has the 80's Miami Vice Deco thing going on which is unique. The crowd isn't a typical Mission crowd- its more laid back and groups sit at tables but you always meet someone new at this bar. Drinks are pretty cheap, its always packed (in a good way) and the lighting makes everyone more attractive. Or is that the drinks?

Check out this bar, but please, don't have boring bitch fights while leaving.
author: Sasha R.

description:
Interesting place.  I like the fact that they're trying to fancy up a little dive bar with their little white tablecloths. . .made me feel like it was ok that I was a little overdressed for this place.  Actually, one of my friends said that I looked "Marina!!!"  WTF??!  Whatev.  My friends and I pretty much took over the back half of this place so that we could bid adieu to one of our friends who is moving away (boo!).  Bartenders are nice, although I think the bartender who my friend said looked like Denise Richards was not too thrilled at that "compliment."   

Well, overall a good night was had by all.  Perhaps I shall return in the future.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Great Art Deco vibe and the drinks are well priced. It can get a little crowed in the small joint but a great first date spot.

Oh no one of my trade secrets are out!
author: Eric T.

description:
This place is so great. It's only a few blocks from my house and everybody's got some bias to good places close to them, but it shines without that.

Great beer, cool art deco decor, used to be a speak easy, owner is cool, women's bathroom is pretty sweet (they all say so), and the staff kicks ass. Example: I left my Timbuk2 bag with my laptop in it there overnight...next morning I called the owner who said a patron had found it and turned it in. Way cool.
author: Mr. R.

description: It a fun place to go on a week day but then the other crowed come out on the weekend  The bartender can pour a strong drink and sometime it hard to find a happy bartender. Go with some friends you will have fun.
author: Betsy W.

description:
I am really conflicted about this place.

As a bar, it is great. The pours are stiff and on price. The bartenders are friendly and attentive (and hot). The vibe is neighborhoody and divey, while being a place you wouldn't be ashamed to drag your parents to and admit you drink there. I also liked the people I met there as they didn't mock me for slurring my words before midnight.

My problem with this place that made me want to start throwing my empty glasses around was how they are trying so hard to make this bar into a lounge. How do they do it? Cram a dozen tables in there so you can hardly move around! Gah! While I was there one night at least 5 people spilled a table of drinks because they were trying to maneuver while being beset by cocktail tables on all sides. It was like a bad movie about zombie furniture hungry for the kneecaps of unsuspecting barflies. I was claustrophobic and the place wasn't even crowded.
author: Matt L.

description:
They revamped the airport completely now it looks just like a night club.
Everyone's excited and confused.

He he. This place is really fun with it's neon lit bar and white cloth covered tables... However, the warning about the lotion in the ladies room is not to be taken lightly.
They make a nice Pimms and lemonade which is quite a luxury in the states.
Go with friends and plan on being friendly if it's busy.
author: kristin n.

description: The Lone Palm is one of the best places to go to have a drink and a conversation. The volume level of music and crowd noise is balanced, which allows you to hear your friend sitting across from you well. The beers on tap are good and the patrons are mostly attractive people without the stuck up attitudes. It's a good mixed of people and I can't think of one thing I would change about the place.
author: Lisa R.

description:
I swear I had written a review on the Palm months ago.  I can even remember what the review talked about...or maybe I just dreamt about yelping it.  Deserving of both a real yelp and a dream-life one, the Palm is one of my favorite places to hang.  The drinks are good and stiff, the clientele is naughty and loose and they have Tobacco-Rose scented hand lotion in the ladies room. 

Gods bless the Palm.
author: Beth G.

description:
Hey, can someone turn on the AC, it's getting HOT in here!  

Spent last Friday tackling this bar with a posse upwards of 20 people, the bar was a little overwhelmed to say the least.  The drinks seemed strong and the bathroom line was always short, two upshots. 

Downside, not much seating and hotter than a motherf&*ker.
author: Claire C.

description:
After attending a particularly bad party and trying to to improve the situation by drinking way too much Jack Daniels rather than doing something intelligent like going somewhere else, I woke up with a massive hangover and no food in the house except for tuna fish.

(As a sidenote, tuna fish is the worst food to vomit, ever. Too salty.)

As usually happens after massive hangovers, I swore off drinking. It lasted eight days. Then I decided to swear off just hard liquor. That lasted for at least a month. Then I went to the Lone Palm.

I never thought I would say this about anywhere, much less a drinking establishment, but the Lone Palm is simply not a beer environment. The dim lighting, cloth tablecloths, Egyptian decor, and odd yesteryear-classy atmosphere drove me to order a gin and tonic. And another. And another. And before long I was staggering to the BART wondering how my resolution had gone so awry and how such strong drinks had been so tasty.

So now, thanks to the Lone Palm, I'm no longer on any wagons. But I have learned to keep my cupboard stocked with some non-tuna fish foods.
author: Liz G.

description: Cute little bar off the beaten path in the Mission.  I had no idea it was here years after hanging in the area.  But, a friend brought me in for a drink the other night and it was like a refuge in the loud, hectic Mission.  It's quiet and cozy in here and I felt right at home.  They have a full bar, but also a good wine selection, which can be hard to find.  Drinks are reasonably priced, which is kind of in contrast to the white tablecloths on the tables.  There are snacky foods (ie. goldfish, potato sticks) on the tables, which I love, because I'm always wanting to snack while drinking.  The music was good and, overall, it was a place I could see myself returning to many times over.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Gather 'round, my children and learn that "The Lone Palm" was once, 'The Mirage".  I lived right up the street in the "Pink Palace" (now green) and my friend Jerry took me down to the Mirage to introduce me to his friend Lynn, one of the bartenders.  Meeting Lynn begat meeting a host of other people important enough to be considered my second family.

Sexy atmosphere?  White tablecloths?  Not for the Mirage!  It was a blue collar (in the best sense of the word) neighborhood bar before the neighborhood became too hip for such places.  It was a bar of Dakota Staten on the jukebox, occasional community pot lucks and a cast of characters no Hollywood screenwriter could imagine (to be truthful not all you would want to spend time with, but that's the way things work out).

After the sale and transformation, it still had a place in my heart for a while and there were still a few memorable characters but then I moved to the wasteland of El Sobrante and even though I'm back in S.F., my visits are infrequent.

Why four stars?  For the memories, baby and it's still a good bar for the neighborhood.

Why not five stars? 'Cause it ain't like it was.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Lone Palm is a third place.  Do you know what a third place is?  Google it.

I love Lone Palm.  It's warm, it's real, it's a great place to meet friends or make new friends.

But beware -- only cool people hang out here, so cool you wouldn't even notice them if they were around.  That's a sign of true cool people.  They keep to themselves yet with the art of subtlety, they let you know they're cool.  And if they aren't cool, you'll know as well.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
The only reason I'm not giving the delightful Lone Palm 5 stars is that it's only a Monday night and I don't know what the vibe would be like on a weekend. But, suffice it to say, I am a fan.
The lights are low, the music is great but unobtrusive, and the drinks are inexpensive and good. 
I met friends for cocktails at the Lone Palm tonight and I have to say I really loved it.  The decor subtly features the eponymous "palm". Two small palm trees guard the front window and small and tasteful palm tree detailing accents the walls. A friendly bartender played cards at the end of the bar with a regular. 
The place is intimate with one main room with a dozen or so tables with tablecloths and candles on them. It's cozy. I'm thinking it'd be a great place for a date.
Nothing too eventful to report but that the Lone Palm is delightful little bar that, if I lived close, I would be happy to make myself a regular at.
author: Carson E.

description:
Love it here and I have no idea why I never hit it up more often. 

It is one of the only bars in my 'hood that I do not feel has been invaded. Come to think of it this bar has all the attributes YOU hate so stay out and go some place else. We want to be alone.
author: Zoe s.

description: Actually has a decent glass of white wine... very rare for a Mission bar. Other pluses - the people gathering there last night all looked friendly, the lighting is flattering, and music was present but not overpowering. It has a nice feel, clean and cozy and you want to stay a little longer.
author: Kirsten S.

description: I am always down for Lone Palm, yet sometimes I don't understand why it's not more 'poppin'... after all, they always play dope background music and lord knows everyone looks good in candlelight. Drinks are a little weaksauce though, if you ask me. In the end, it's a great option when you're looking for a (slightly) more mature neighborhood bar in the Mission where you can actually hear the people you're with. Bottoms up!
author: Stephanie P.

description: I liked the vibe and the cocktail was yummy. The service was average. Would go back there.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Good for what it is, but they don't stock a very wide variety of liquors, and you don't get the sense that this is the sort of place where you could order something complicated and have it done well, or even done right.

The atmosphere is sweet -- frayed-at-the-edges Deco -- and props for the little bowls of nibbles on the tables.
author: anita c.

description:
When my friend from LA came to visit, I took him here for a drink.  Little did I realize that the place itself has a very strong LA vibe, between the palm tree motifs, the art deco, the white tablecloths and candles, and the silent movies playing.  How ironic.

Nevertheless, this is a great place to chill and talk over cocktails.  As reviewer a p so perfectly put it, this is not a dive bar, it's a lounge that's so ultra-low-key it just gets mistaken for one.
author: Wes M.

description:
With so many bars in the city and having to put in so much darn effort to dress up, dress down, attitude up, hipster nonchalance in, flirt out, or bat eyelashes for the occasion, I almost gave up on finding the right place to just chill and permanently relegate myself to the comforts of my own home bar. 

Until.
Lone Palm.

When my friend said, "Hey let's go to a bar in the Mission that you haven't been to," and I think, "Oh man, my only pair of skinny jeans are in the wash. Sh--t. I don't care." So I held my breath and prayed to not be socially ostracized.

Walked in, and I experienced that instant feeling of having my breath suctioned away from me and exhaling in a big sigh of relief that this is like my home bar. Except instead of drinking for one, I can bring all my friends here and merrily drink and socialize together. Comfort and space is respected by well-spaced out round tables for a conversation with a date or huddling with friends. I find it amusing that the table have white linen cloth on it, but that is the character that makes the place intimate and brings down the typical bar rowdy factor. The bartenders acknowledge your presence and so sweet on their pours. I brought in a burrito to eat, and no one even noticed.

I don't just like this bar. I LOVE this bar.
author: Cathy H.

description: On weekdays this place has a really calming, mellow atmosphere.  Low lights, classic bar and what seem like regular patrons.  Feels like a movie scene.
author: Bhrina P.

description:
Disclaimer: I've been away from the bar scene due to pregnancy  - I mean I know it's ok to have a glass of wine every now and then, but really now, if I caved every time someone told me that when I was pregnant, then this baby would have had some seriously far set eyes -  Eyes to the front, not to the side! Hunter! not Prey!   Anyhoo - 

Small with cinematic lighting - very noir -

I like it!
author: Robyn C.

description:
It's like a bastardized LA dive stereotype dropped into the Mission somewhere near the nightly SF fog line. It's very feaux-Art Deco which is cool. White tablecloths, a candle, some goldfish, and the drink of your choice are what sit in front you. It's pretty dark inside. But its romantic in its half-ass attempts at southern-california cool.

That said, we're still in the Mission, this is still San Francisco. Most of the people inside are hodge podge of hipster, aging hipsters, and outer-mission folk. Not that that's a bad thing. They've got Boont Amber for $3.50. Other drinks aren't that bad either. It's never too crowded ad you can usually get a table.

This is a great place if you're in the mood for sitting with friends, drinking, faking your hipsterness, and soaking in some slightly different surroundings.
author: Tolga E.

description: The Lone Palm is the chillest bar in the Mission.
author: Klevin D.

description:
Best Bar Ever. I love this place and it's not just b/c it is one of the closest to my house. 
This is actually a perfect first date bar. It is dark enough, the drinks are strong enough, and if you get there early in the evening it is not slammed. Busy factor is really hit or miss but you can always find a spot at the bar or a table. Sometimes they even have theme nights on Fridays where the bartenders dress up honky tonk, disco, fun stuff. Chelsea is also the best bartender ever.
author: Roxane S.

description:
Whats not to love about Lone Palm? After a long week at work, I met up with two friends of mine for a night out. We decided to give Lone Palm a shot and had a drink there before moving on for dinner. 

The atmosphere is great....low key and with just enough people to make it fun, but not to the point of being obnoxiously crowded or loud. The drinks were solid....and reasonably priced.

I will definitely be back
author: Jenn G.

description: Mission dive type bar. It gets very busy, crowded with mostly mission hipsters. Drinks are moderately priced. I don't know if i would go out of my way from NOMA to go here but if i were in the neighborhood, I would stop by again. Stick with beer here.
author: Ka C.

description:
I love the fact that I live a few doors down from the Lone Palm. If I've had a few too many, I can just stagger home.

The Lone Palm is a nice, unpretentious bar that draws a mixed (gay and straight) crowd. It can get a bit hectic on the weekends, but everyone is pretty friendly, so it's all good.

And they make kick-ass martinis.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
I really like Lone Palm, but the place has become very popular over the years, and it's often packed.  Several bartenders there can't make a vodka gimlet.  

That said, it's a great low-key place to meet on a weeknight.

What's up with that Egyptian woman on the wall with one tit?
author: Des Esseintes I.

description:
This is one of the few places in the mission where one can get together with a group of friends, sit at a table (that has tablecloths) and talk.  Although off and on, it got quite noisy and was difficult to hear each other under the piercing irritating bleats from this girl sitting at the table behind us.  (One of the guys at our table had a slight hangover).  

Sometimes you can smell cigarette smoke in there, and i'm not sure if it's from people smoking from outside and it's wafting in or if someone was sneaking a smoke indoors.

Nice ambience, people were nicely dressed here.  I'll have to remember this place for future reference!
author: Animal K.

description:
The bartender here made me a great margarita.  The scene is a bit strange and the tables don't do much for the claustrophobia.  There were loud, drunk people in there so I don't blame the bartenders for the bad attitude.    

Probably best to check it out on a non-weekend night.  Might be less crowded?
author: Melissa Y.

description:
I'd lived in the neighborhood for quite a while and never tried Lone Palm, since the dark doorway and neon sign had me convinced it was the kind of place where you'd get heckled by crusty old men with beer guts who haven't seen daylight since last week. BUT NO! You just have to step inside to see that it's actually pretty nice, with candlelight and tablecloths and all. It's definitely a spot for youngish folks, has cool music, low lighting, good for a date or catching up with a few friends. It's usually quiet enough that you can actually hear each other talking, too. Sometimes they have $3 drink specials (yay) although choose wisely -- I've had a few cocktails here that were weaker than a baby monkey's bicep...as they say. 

Overall a very cool, unpretentious and definitely unexpected neighborhood drink spot. Try it out!
author: J P.

description:
I like the play on words in the name, otherwise I found it unremarkable.
There was a really cute bartender who kept messing up on my order, but thats ok, I didn't seem to mind.
author: Tom S.

description:
Didn't read the reviews before I headed out the door, so I was expecting a "lounge" a found a high dive. Have to agree on the "ultra-low-key-that-it-looks-like-a-dive" comment. 

BUT, I do have ONE unique thing to add-- KAT is AMAZING. 
No joke. But Miss Kat, who is the super cute bahtendah from Southie is uber cool and her drinks are top notch. She used to tend at a not-to-be-mentioned chic NYC club in Chelsea (I've said too much) and she has 12 drinks to her name. Tried three-- "yellow cake deliciousness", "chocolate raspberry ice cream drippings" and "hi-yah limeade!" These are all names I just made up. Haha.

But yes, if Miss Kat is not too busy, ask her to surprise you! For a low key lounge, this woman knows how to make a high-class cocktail!
author: Miss C.

description:
I give the Lone Palm 4 stars 'cause there are really a lot worse bars you could be in.

I don't give it 5 'cause there are better.  

Still its got white tablecloths and soothing lighting, and that goes a long way.  The real secret about the place is that it's where everyone goes when they're having a drink with someone they don't want anyone else to see them having a drink with.
author: Gustie L.

description:
What a great little place for a super cocktail.  cute little neon sign, small residential street, always some good peanuts at the bar, and pretty good drinks (ok, not the BEST, but not bad).  

if you want a nice place to have a great drink and some good conversation with a few friends...definitely hit it.
author: Nancy R.

description:
Cozy, affordable, and a block off the well-beaten path.  Tablecloths and friendly service give Lone Palm more class than its average patron.  35 humans in this place make it 35 degrees (celsius).  The soundtrack even had some not-on-the-radio Radiohead songs the other night.

I don't understand why some posters call it a dive bar.  Also, it's not good for groups, unless your group is content to stand three-deep at the bar.
author: Rawley V.

description:
I love Lone Palm. Its within stumbling distance of my parent's house (convenient for those trips home ouch), dark (convenient because I can't be arsed to put on makeup at home), and doesn't play anything particularly offensive. It was more fun when they let you smoke, but still this remains one of my favourite semi-classy dive bars, with awesome bartenders and generally non-douchy patronage, plus the bathrooms are usually decent.

All in all, if I had to pass out on the floor of a dive bar, it would be this one.
author: Poonam S.

description:
Was meeting friends at 22nd and Guerrero at some bar, didn't they didn't tell me which one, so I posted up with a newspaper about 10 minutes early w/ a newspaper and enjoyed the sun.  I was in front of one of those lounges that that has no windows and is completely dark in the day where alcoholics who drink Martinis and want to pretend it isn't the middle of the day go to avoid doing real things.  Well it happens that this is the bar we were meeting.  

No my friends are not taking me into some dark lounge on a sunny September day, I whined for a few minutes until they put about 3 different dishes with bar snacks in front of me.  Bar snacks will add at least 1 or 2 stars to any bar review.  I ate goldfish and beer for about 3 hours, enjoyed the atmosphere and bizarre mix of people, but don't waste a sunny day to go there.
author: Colin D.

description: I give it 5 stars although it's really a 4.5. Friendly staff. Boozy atmosphere. Dog friendly, which is why I give it a 5 and not a 4. Don't expect much and you shall receive. This was  our local haunt, before we moved. I miss it and enjoy going back.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Lone Palm is simply great. The bartender makes *excellent* drinks- and actually knows what you are talking about when you want a sidecar, Manhattan, old-fashioned, etc. There are many tables in this joint and even if you do what we did (walk in around 11pm on a Saturday), you can wait around for a few minutes and score a place to sit. 

The crowd is pretty interesting for people watching- a range of styles and ages.

The only complaint I would have about this place is that it has become a bit popular- but hell, I'm yelping about it, so I guess I'm not complaining too much!
author: Rebecca A.

description:
everyone has a favorite neighborhood bar and i'm so effing proud to say that lone palm is mine... and yes, if you want to stalk me, this is where you can find me about twice a week, but you're buying the drink. so you need to weigh that factor before you get all undercover on me.

anyway, there is something comforting and familiar about lone palm. perhaps it's the name that takes me back to my adolescent days with my right hand (sometimes left hand cuz it's like having sex with someone new) and hand lotion. ahhhh, those were the good old days! nothing to worry about except for getting good grades and not getting caught by mom during the lone palm performances. and yes, i called it a performance cuz i got quite creative. i mean, it's not like i had access to liquid silk or good vibrations back then... nowadays i sit comfortably at the lone palm bar with a beer bottle sans the hand lotion and reminisce the good old days... johnson, monkey, dolphin, beer bottle. same thing, different texture. all i need to complete the aforementioned list is a remote control to the lone palm tv.

oh, who am i kidding. i still use the lone palm, but i don't fist.
author: frisco j.

description: A true gem.  This was one of the first bars I visited in SF.  Now that I live here I went back to see if it had changed.  Not a bit.  White tablecloths, BUGLES in bowls on the tables.  The friendly barmistress made me a kickass Old Fashioned then a Horse's Neck, which she claimed was Humphrey Bogard's favorite.  It was MY favorite.  Lone Palm is my favorite.
author: Eric S.

description:
I gotta say that this is a great "date bar", even though I took a wildly attractive, high-maintenance woman here for a drink once and things went awry (not on the fault of the bar).  It's is a lousy place to show up by yourself and try to connect with strangers, but a great place (if not the ONLY ONE in the area) where you can sit, sip, and communicate with a date in a reasonably swank environment, and do so without fighting off Lotharios or straining to talk over loud music.  

I'd been seeing her for awhile, and whenever we went out for a drink she'd order the same thing:

"A double-tall greyhound with a big glass of water".

I settled for a beer, but gazed with trepidation while the bartender mixed my dates drink.  I could have read somebody their Miranda rights during the time the bottle was fully inverted over the glass.  I order a second beer when she's about half way done with her drink, and she chimes in and orders another one too.  I watch the bartender while he mixed her second, and again the bottle went inverted-vertical.  Familiar words went through my head:  "You have the right to remain silent...anything you say can or will...".  Somewhere around "...provided for you at government expense", he flipped the bottle back up again.  It took her awhile to finish her first drink....after which we decided to get something to eat.  An untouched double-tall Greyhound sat beckoning on on the bar. I pointed to it and said "You DON'T have to drink that" right before  starting to pull a hooded sweatshirt over my head.  My hands went through the sleeves and my head poked out into open view only to see her holding the glass to her lips at a 45 degree angle, after which she defiantly slammed the empty glass on the bar and flashed me her best "don't tell me what to do" shit-eating-grin.

Ever watch the old "Road Runner" cartoons?  Ever see what Wiley Coyote looks like after a failed attempt at Road-Runner hunting and a big rock drops on his head?  The rolling eyes, the staggering gait, the slurred speech and a complete loss of all basic motor skills?  That's what my date looked like the second we stepped outside and the cold air hit her. I poured her in a cab and got her back to my place. When we got home, I pointed to the couch...."That's where you're sleeping".  The next morning she couldn't find her car keys. I went looking for them...no luck.

Dinner at Savor:           $30.00
2 Rounds of Drinks:    $24.00
Short Cab Ride :          $ 5.00

Telling the hottest woman you've ever dated
 "I told you so":              PRICELESS!!!

For everything else, there's Master Card...

So if you're looking for a quiet place to unwind and converse with a date after a night on the town, give Lone Palm a checking out.  It's nice without noise.  There's a scene, but not a crowd.  There's style, but without pretentiousness.  Bring your dates, but leave your beer buddies at home.  And watch out for the greyhounds....THEY BITE!
author: Mike W.

description:
my mini-me's favorite dive bar in san francisco...

i just don't get it...
the white table cloths..... why???  it bothers me because i can't stop wondering why they use white table cloths....
the only thing that makes somewhat sense of this place is that yes there is a lone palm in front of the entrance.... but with that too.... why???
author: charlotte s.

description: I've never been to a bar where the bar tenders were so inept.  They both passed me and girlfriend at least 3 times to go have shots with their douchebag friends in the corner.  When we finally got our drinks, she gave my change to her friends and just walked away.  I did get my change back from them, but that turned into a huge f*cking mess, as the drunk douches brought out their territorial ass-holeness.  The management should show up on a saturday night to check out the poor service.  I think I'll drink elsewhere.
author: Samir S.

description: Any bar name that connotes masturbation deserves at least 3 stars.  The fact that I've never gotten any action here at all makes it a decent predictor as well, so there's your other star.  Excellent grown-up bar.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: My new favorite bar. Very low key (at least on the Tuesday I was there), classy, tasty drinks, bar nuts, great tunes played at the perfectly talk overable level. Yay - great bar!
author: Colin S.

description: When you were thirteen, this is the kind of bar you imagined that your really cool older cousin hung out in. Probably the kind of place Phillip K. Dick would have frequented if he were a child of the '80s.  The darker version latter-years Miami Vice neon chic seems to have been cryogenically preserved and then implanted into this place, the ne plus ultra neighborhood undive.  The perfect place to escape the warm happy sunny smiling afternoon and lurk in its shadowy womb.  They also serve a great Manhattan.
author: Gabriel S.

description: The chinese got it right with the round table thing (aside from it being a natural fit with a round lazy susan).  Nothing like a round table to make people feel close.  And the Lone Palm has a delightful sprinkling of little round tables with people laughing and talking and talking and laughing over them.
author: Audrey T.

description:
i'm not sure if it's due to their recent write ups in style and culture magazines or if they're simply allowing certain things fall to the wayside, but the lone palm has been letting me down lately.

first, there's the oft-discussed issue of the manner in which they wash their glasses - leaving so much soap scum in/on the glasses that your beer ends up with soap head on top of the beer head. it has happened in all of the times i have been in recently (about five times in the past two months) and so much so that discussions have centered around actually taking in our own glasses to the bar. convenience of location does actually beat out ignoring the bar altogether. although, this next item could change even that ability to overlook a shortcoming.

second, the last time i went into the bar, i was double charged for my drinks. once on the morning after i had actually gone in to the bar and a second time a few days later, without having gone back in to the bar. this is a big negative for someone who already doesn't have the disposable income in the first place.

finally, they have taken cider off tap, meaning i can no longer drink a snakebite at this establishment.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: Ah, those were the days. Satin evening gowns with rhinestone brooches, fedoras and trench coats. Bogey and Bacall. White table cloths with flickering candles in the center. Soak up the glamour and actually hear what your companion is saying as you sip your dirty gin martini. If you're sitting at the bar, they have these sly little hooks hiding under the counter for your purse. I love it when bars do that.
author: Katrina D.

description: Good bar. Minus one star because - Can they get the tables any closer together? Seriously, the 2 tables we occupied made it impossible for people to get past us without someone, or even 2 people, getting up. Lose a few: tables. Guinness on tap makes me happy. A friend said her Vodka Tonic was good. Oh yeah, the bartender was hot.
author: Ken L.

description: This bar is smelly and full of similar looking hippie douche bags. I can love the environment but this bar just makes me wanna vomit
author: Luke R.

description: Great bar for a cocktail on a weekday. I always chose the bar as the tables with table cloths are formal for me. On weekend nights it gets pretty packed with a late night scene that can be pretty fun. All in all a good bar to have in the neighborhood.
author: Julia W.

description: white linen covered....individual candle lighting per table seating...but, bar ordering..mission district bar....less crowded...group seating plenty.....decent bar, but curious to why so lax 'n' empty....while other mission bar/lounge packed to max sunday night.....stocking full....oban, mccallen and glenlivet to grey goose and more.....standard pours..not full..not small....good bartender at work...in lone palm...alone less crowded in mission off to side....
author: Hen A.

description: Kind of pricey drinks, but fantastic bartenders. A refuge away from the chaos of Valencia & Mission Street. You used to be able to smoke in here, but I think they got in trouble for that and have since suspended it.  They always have great movies playing on the TV (usually black and white, occasionally art movies) and Chex mix on each table, which has certainly come in handy when the whiskey starts to hit a little too hard.  A fabulous bar.
author: Maria D.

description: You talk about bars in the mission and most people assume it's a bit divey and loud.  But the Lone Palm classes up the joint without losing sight of where it's located and the people who like to go.
